headline: 'I told Sir Alex Ferguson he wouldn't be sacked as dire Man Utd run made him fear for job'
body: Manchester United's legendary manager Sir Alex Ferguson endured some rocky periods during his time at Old Trafford, but the most famous story about his job isn't all it seems

As Sir Alex Ferguson won more and more trophies at Manchester United, the story about him being one defeat from the sack back in 1990 grew legs, but the man who had the power to hand the Scot his P45 has revealed that was never the case.

The story goes that United's form in the 1989-90 season left Ferguson under pressure around the turn of the year. Eight winless games put extra strain on the FA Cup third-round meeting with Nottingham Forest, with defeat potentially the final straw for the manager.
Mark Robins scored the winner, supposedly saving the boss, and United ended the season as cup winners. The rest was history, so they say.

Except there's one small problem. United chairman Martin Edwards would have been the man tasked with sacking Ferguson if his team lost to Forest, and Edwards himself has explained that was never on the cards.

“I spoke to him in the week leading up to the Forest game, and said that if we did lose, it wasn’t going to result in the sack," Edwards told FourFourTwo. “I wanted to give him that comfort before the game.

“Coming second flattered us in 1988 – the team needed strengthening and probably his management helped us get to that position, but we weren’t good enough to win the title. “We were patient, particularly during 1989-90, because we’d bought five players and had to give them time to gel.

“He’d revamped the whole scouting system and we could see the work going on with the youth team, so we felt it was worth supporting. We had faith that success would arrive, but I’m glad it arrived when it did because we were coming under pressure from fans and everyone else."

United didn't immediately recover in the league. Indeed, they lost their next two to leave relegation as a distinct possibility, but seven wins from the final 14 games led them to the relative comfort of 13th place.

The momentum came from the cup run, though. After away wins against Hereford, Newcastle and Sheffield United, Ferguson's team needed replays in both the semis and the final to bring their manager his first silverware in English football.

There was steady improvement over the next two seasons, too. Sixth place and a Cup Winners' Cup win in 1990-91, second place and a League Cup win the following year, and then the first of Ferguson's 13 Premier League titles in 1993.

Ferguson also poured cold water on the suggestions he was one game for dismissal, sharing his recollection ahead of a meeting with a Barnsley side managed by Robins in 2009. "The goal at Forest was an important goal, don’t get me wrong, and who's to say what would have happened without it, but I don’t think it saved my job," he said.

"You never know in football. Who's to say how the club would have reacted if we'd lost and if crowds had tumbled? Although it was unusual for United crowds to do that. One thing's for sure though - Bobby Charlton would not have let it [my sacking] happen. He knows better than anyone the heartbeat of this football club.
"This football club needed the foundation of youth and we were doing some great work there. Bobby knew we were on the right road."

headline: Why Liverpool hiring Xabi Alonso to replace Jurgen Klopp could cause Man Utd huge problem
body: Former Liverpool midfielder Xabi Alonso has emerged as one of the favourites to replace Jurgen Klopp at Anfield, and the appointment could have repercussions for Manchester United
Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag could end up being targeted by Bayer Leverkusen if the Bundesliga leaders lose manager Xabi Alonso to Liverpool.

Alonso, 42, has been touted as a replacement for Jurgen Klopp when the German ends his nine-year spell at Anfield at the end of the season. Spain international Alonso spent several years on Liverpool's books as a player, winning the Champions League in 2005 and reaching the final of the same competition two years later.

As revealed by Mirror Football, Ten Hag's long-term future as United boss could hinge on how much money he is given to spend in the summer. United made no new additions in January, with Ten Hag indicating Financial Fair Play concerns prevented him from bringing in the new striker he wanted.

Ten Hag has never managed in the Bundesliga before, but he developed an affinity for the league during his time in charge of Bayern Munich's second string. The manager was born in the east of the Netherlands, near the border with Germany, and still owns a house near the border.

"It's not a secret that I wanted a striker extra," Ten Hag said in his pre-match press conference ahead of Sunday's home meeting with West Ham. "Because with the injury of [Anthony] Martial, we don't really have back-up there, but it was not possible because we have to match the Financial Fair Play rules.

"We have Omari (Forson), we have Amad Diallo, of course, we have Rashford who can play there. I think for the rest, all the positions are occupied. But, yeah, we have to be a little bit creative if it's up to the number nine position."

United are the lowest scorers in the top half of the Premier League, despite putting four past Wolves in their last game. Ten Hag has overseen the arrival of big-money signings across two summer windows, but the coming summer could prove just as significant.

Alonso doesn't appear to have let the Liverpool talk distract him from the task at hand. Leverkusen claimed a 2-0 victory at Darmstadt to remain two points clear of their closest title challengers Bayern Munich ahead of their meeting next Saturday, with Nathan Tella scoring both goals.

"Bayern is always Bayern, so to beat them you have to beat them not once, [but] twice or three times," Alonso said. "But before that we have the Pokal game [against Stuttgart on Tuesday] that is a big one for us We want to keep going - let's see how far, but we don't want to stop."

Bayern were given a fright in their own Saturday fixture at home to Borussia Monchengladbach, but eventually claimed all three points. Nico Elvedi put Gladbach in front, only for Aleksandar Pavlovic to equalise just before half-time, with second-half goals from Harry Kane and Matthijs de Ligt giving Bayern victory.

headline: Erik ten Hag explains Manchester United players' celebratory picture
body: Man United have won their last three games and scored 11 goals with their youngest starters at the forefront of their form.
Erik ten Hag believes Manchester United are starting to fulfil their potential with a fuller squad available.
United have won all three games since a 13-day winter break, scoring 11 goals against Newport County, Wolves and West Ham.

Rasmus Hojlund has been on target in all three triumphs, Alejandro Garnacho took his tally for the season to seven against West Ham while Kobbie Mainoo netted his first two goals for the club at Newport and Wolves.

The three youngsters came together for a celebratory pose to mark Garnacho's first goal in the 3-0 defeat of West Ham, sitting together on the Old Trafford advertising hoarding. Garnacho mimicked West Ham winger Mohammed Kudus's celebration and described it as an "inspiration".

Garnacho has started the past 18 games while Mainoo has lined up in 11 of the last 15 games since he returned from injury. The midfielder suffered an ankle injury in United's second pre-season tour match against Real Madrid in July that sidelined Mainoo for four months.
"I have to analyse, clinical, calm," Ten Hag explained of United's mini resurgence. "So we now have a team that is in balance on the pitch. We can play better, also you see the progress is coming.
"We bought players in the summer for the future, we also made choices to give players who deserve it, to give opportunities in the first team such as Garnacho and Mainoo.
"Mainoo in the second game against Madrid gets a real bad injury. Then the plans you have, you have to adapt. Hojlund had a period, he came late in, young, but you see he is progressing.

"When there is a consistent team in his back with routines, they will serve him better and you see a frontline in balance. It is a threat for every opponent and also you see they enjoy it, to play football, they enjoy it, to give opponents problems, they want to do the togetherness.

"The picture covered a lot, I think, of the three youngsters celebrating together. It's not about one player, it's about a team. That's what I have seen today. It looked like a team. 11 defending, 11 attacking. For me, it was enjoyable to watch.

"That was our plan before the season because we saw the potential from those players. They need games, they need experience and the only way you get this is to play in the first team, to get the opposition, then adapt and have the right attitude and they keep doing this in togetherness and the attitude to improve every day. Then I am convinced they can achieve very high levels.
"But they need experienced players, who've achieved everything to help them, to put them in the right positions. Right moment and right attitude."
Manchester United continued their improved form with a 3-0 victory over West Ham on Sunday.
The Red Devils earned a third consecutive victory after Rasmus Hojlund's opener was followed by a second-half brace from Alejandro Garnacho. United's victory moved them up to sixth in the table.

One negative story coming from Old Trafford however was the injury to influential centre-back Lisandro Martinez. The Argentine was substituted in the second half of Sunday's win, with manager Erik ten Hag offering a bleak outlook on the severity of Martinez's latest injury blow.

When it comes to transfer news, reports have claimed that United could have added a new striker on deadline day in the shape of Borussia Dortmund's Sebastien Haller. Elsewhere, Benfica goalkeeper Anatoliy Trubin has been mentioned as a potential Manchester United summer signing by his agent.
Man United legend Alan Smith has heaped praise on Red Devils striker Rasmus Højlund.

"I think Højlund is going to get better and better," he said via BritishGambler.co.uk. "It’s difficult for him to lead the line and play as a single striker on his own at the minute, but he will develop into a great number 9 for United.

"Just having a little bit of time will help him. The team obviously hasn’t hit the ground running and it was a difficult period when he came in, but I think he’s starting to get the rewards and scoring the goal has helped him.

"I just feel that he has all the attributes to be a really good centre forward; he’s quick, he holds the ball up well – there’s a lot of positives for him but it hasn’t been easy, because the team hasn’t been playing as well as possible, but there have been sparks where you have seen the quality that he’s got. The more confidence he gets, the better he will become."
If Sir Jim Ratcliffe corrects just one department at Manchester United this forthcoming summer, it has to be the recruitment department.

For far too long, United have been guilty of over-spending on players, courtesy of poor strategic planning and rash decision-making. As part of their minority investment at Old Trafford, INEOS have secured management of the club's football operations, meaning they will oversee all aspects of recruitment.

INEOS, of course, have acted swiftly to try and lay the foundations for a brighter future on that particular front, swooping for Omar Berrada, who has been installed as the club's new CEO, from Manchester City. He has already warned about the dangers of paying over the odds for players - something United have been guilty of time after time.
READ MORE HERE
Manchester United defender Diogo Dalot has sent a heartfelt message to Lisandro Martinez after the Argentine suffered another injury concern.
"Your pain is our pain. You will be back soon my brother," he wrote in an Instagram story post.
READ MORE HERE
Hello and welcome to our live updates on all the latest Manchester United news.
A good win yesterday for Ten Hag's team who are starting to build some momentum amid a difficult season.
One major concern of course is the injury to Lsiandro Martinez. We'll provide you with the latest on the centre-back as and when we get it.
The United striker celebrated his birthday in style by opening the scoring against West Ham. Is there a better way to celebrate turning 21? Happy Birthday, Rasmus.
Portuguese outlet Record claim that Saudi side Al Hilal will renew interest in Manchester United captain Bruno Fernandes in the summer after being knocked back in January.

The report says that Fernandes himself responded 'negatively' to a potential January move to the club. But it adds that they will not give up and will return again when the summer transfer window opens.
Fernandes will have two years remaining on his deal at Old Trafford when the summer comes around.

West Ham manager David Moyes has said that he thinks the scoreline against United was harsh on his side. The former United boss was happy with his team's performance and said the main difference was that they didn't take their chances when they came.

"No I don't think the scoreline was correct," the Scot told Match of the Day. "Our performance in the main was much better. I am pleased with that but obviously not pleased with different aspects, we didn't finish chances. Overall we played better and our performance was better today."

"We have been on a pretty good run without being at our best, with some players also away," he added. "I thought today we looked like it but goals have been a little hard to come by. Hopefully there's a wee bit of mitigating circumstances and hopefully the goals will start flowing in the coming weeks."
The United striker has made an exciting comment on how the young team continues to develop.

"I think it was about a month ago when I was doing an interview on the pitch and we were talking about the squad as a whole not scoring enough goals," he told Sky Sports after the match. "We’re young, I just turned 21 and he’s 19 but we’re getting better everyday. You can see the connection now in the squad, it’s growing between me, Garna[cho], Antony, Rashford, Bruno.
Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag has described Lisandro Martinez's apparent knee injury as a "personal disaster".
Martinez's knee buckled under the weight of West Ham defender Vladimir Coufal in the 66th minute of United's 3-0 Premier League win at Old Trafford and he was forced off in the 71st minute.
Ten Hag was unable to provide a specific prognosis on the injury but said it was "very bad" and Martinez was "very sad".
"I can't say, it doesn't look good so there's a big concern, but we have to wait for the coming days what the diagnosis is then we can tell you more."
Read more here.
Roy Keane has praised United for their performance against West Ham, with both Hojlund and Garnacho picked out.

"They were very good this afternoon, Manchester United, they were always first to the ball and they started very quickly," he told Sky Sports. "It was game over after the second goal for me, and the way I look at their third goal - Kalvin Phillips, he’s sluggish in this one. [Scott] McTominay does really well, a nice weighted pass into the path of Garnacho and a calm finish. Solid afternoon for United, they’re back in good form, nice and aggressive, game over."
Rasmus Hojlund has explained the celebration for the opening goal in this afternoon's 3-0 win over West Ham.

"It is always good to play on your birthday," he told Sky Sports. "I have spoken about doing celebrations with my friends and they told me to do a guitar in the summer. I hadn't done it yet, but today was the day."
The United boss has given a worrying update on the defender after he was taken off in the second half with a knee injury.
It was just the defender's fourth game back after returning from a foot injury but it now seems that he could face some time on the sidelines.
It was a good afternoon for United at Old Trafford for United as they came out as 3-0 winners over West Ham.
Goals from Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho (x2) made it a comfortable afternoon. There was however one worry to come from the game.
Defender Lisandro Martinez was forced off in the second half with a suspected knee problem. He went down in the 66th minute but was able to continue after receiving treatment.
He however lasted just another five minutes before going down again. Erik ten Hag will give an update on the player in his post-match press conference.
Manchester United loanee Donny van de Beek has been handed a blow during his loan spell with German side Eintracht Frankfurt.
The midfielder completed a loan move away from Old Trafford early in the January transfer window. But it has not yet gone to plan.

He has made three league appearances for the club, but was an unused substitute against FC Koln this weekend. It has now emerged that the United man has been left out of the club's Europa Conference League squad.
"I think he’d certainly want to go out on a high," Roy Keane told Sky Sports when discussing the departure of Jurgen Klopp at United's bitter rivals.

"I think if there was any competition they’d want to win, it’d be the Premier League just because even when they won it a few years ago, it was the Covid season and they didn’t get the chance to enjoy it as much.

"His legacy is obviously incredible, we’ve spoken so much about him over the last few weeks about his achievements and what he’s done for the league, his win percentage, trophies, style of football. But if he can leave with one or two trophies, it’d be icing on the cake.
"I certainly wouldn’t begrudge them a league title, obviously Manchester United are well out of it, but I wouldn’t begrudge any team that wins the league title because they’d deserve it."
Utd XI: Onana, Dalot, Maguire, Martinez, Shaw, Casemiro, Mainoo, Fernandes, Garnacho, Rashford, Hojlund.
Subs: Bayinder, Varane, Lindelof, Amrabat, Diallo, Eriksen, Antony, McTominay, Forson.
West Ham XI: Areola, Coufal, Johnson, Aguerd, Zouma, Emerson, Soucek, Alvarez, Kudus, Ward-Prowse, Bowen.
Subs: Fabianski, Cresswell, Ogbonna, Ings, Cornet, Scarles, Mubama, Mavropanos, Phillips.
United are understandable favourites for this afternoon's game against West Ham.
But matches have very rarely been won easily by Ten Hag's side this season.
Still, the Hammers have not won since December 28 against Arsenal so United should be confident.

West Ham 4/1
Erik ten Hag named his strongest Manchester United side against Wolves. They still nearly managed to throw it all away.

There were certainly positives to take from the dominant performance, and on another day, it might well have been a victory by a far bigger margin, but the harsh truth is that it wasn't. It was the same story against Newport a week ago. United could have won by a three- or four-goal margin but instead, they threw away another lead when they should have been comfortable.
Yet it would still be a surprise if they chose to make any changes today. Ten Hag has regularly cited his ambition of having a settled squad, and now he has the opportunity to do just that.
READ MORE HERE
Erik ten Hag admits that Manchester United's thrilling 4-3 win over Wolves on Thursday gave "some headaches".

"Yeah, we were, of course, very pleased with the win," he said via the club's website. "It was a match with many stories and we are pleased with our levels - in the first hour, I would say, especially the first 45 minutes.

"But after that, we should have killed the game and we didn’t. We let them return but then the team showed character and got the win, so I’m happy for our fans. I would say it was a thriller, I think. For the neutral spectator, it was also very nice to watch this game. But for a manager, it gives some headaches."

"Since then though, look at the job he is doing at West Ham, he won a trophy, is pushing for Europe again and they are still in the Europa League.

"Man United, well they need results, especially at home where they have lost too many matches. They need to take the attention away from what’s happening off the pitch, so I’ll go with them to win this one at home."
Of all the Ajax players Ten Hag could have signed, Kudus was arguably the one best suited to their attacking line. He cost less than half the price as well.

The Ghanaian is back from the Africa Cup of Nations and won a vital penalty for West Ham on Thursday night, shortly before Antony nearly cost his team with his careless loss of possession that led to a late Wolves equaliser.
United will hope to subdue Kudus this time around, but rather than a battle against Antony, he will have to try and outshine Alejandro Garnacho instead. It'll be a tough ask.

Manchester United are reportedly set to hand Kobbie Mainoo a new and improved contract following his sensational performances this season.

The 18-year-old signed a fresh deal last February following his first-team debut a few weeks earlier. Mainoo has grown immensely since then and has become an important starting XI figure despite his tender age.

He grabbed his first Premier League goal with a dramatic 97th-minute winner against Wolves on Thursday after another impressive showing. Mainoo’s current deal runs until 2027 but could soon have his stay extended. The academy graduate will not be offered new terms before the summer in a bid to avoid distraction from his on-field form.

Erik ten Hag has praised Rasmus Hojlund's "resilience and calmness" after lauding his £72millon striker for starting to live up to the expectations he has set himself at Manchester United.

The 20-year-old endured a difficult start to his Old Trafford career in a team that was losing its way, but although the goals didn't flow for Hojlund, his attitude never changed and he never went missing.

Ten Hag revealed the striker was getting "angry and mad" as he went 14 Premier League games without a goal since his summer switch from Atalanta, but after breaking his duck against Aston Villa he has now scored in three successive top-flight games, taking his tally in all competitions to nine this season.

Hello and welcome to our live blog on all the latest Manchester United news.
There have been plenty of false dawns at United this season so let's see if Thursday's win over Wolves is a turning point.

West Ham have struggled in recent weeks having not won since beating Arsenal on December 28, but expect David Moyes to make it difficult for his former team at Old Trafford with patience likely to be needed.
Stick with us throughout the day for all the latest.
Making comparisons between established and young players is often not helpful but it's inevitable.
Kobbie Mainoo has been likened to Paul Pogba and his performance for Manchester United's Under-21s against Salford City in October intensified the comparisons.
Mainoo recorded two assists and he sprayed some beautiful passes under the floodlights. His movement was reminiscent of Pogba's.
Mainoo was carefully handled after his return from injury and he featured for the U21s in a handful of games, but it was only a matter of time before Erik ten Hag gave him opportunities.
Shola Shoretire faces an uncertain future at Manchester United after dropping down the pecking order, even though the club is hoping he signs a new deal.
The academy graduate celebrated his 20th birthday on Friday and is now at an awkward crossroads where he is untested at youth level and needs to be playing regular football at senior level.
Shoretire made his first-team debut at the age of just 17 and still holds the record as the youngest player to represent United in European competition.
United loanee Jadon Sancho missed Borussia Dortmund's goalless draw with Heidenheim on Friday night due to an injury.
Sancho joined the Bundesliga giants on loan in January after a public fallout with United manager Erik ten Hag.
The forward has made three appearances and bagged two assists since returning to Germany.
A report from HITC says Gareth Southgate is reportedly considering handing Kobbie Mainoo his senior England debut.
The midfielder is also eligible to play for Ghana with the country's FA stating their intentions to try and convince him to play for the African nation.
Even if Mainoo plays for England in March's friendlies, he is still able to switch allegiances with this only being ruled out upon a competitive debut. Mainoo has six caps for the Under-19s.
Rasmus Hojlund says Manchester United’s young players, including Kobbie Mainoo, have created a group chat between them on social media to build camaraderie within the dressing room.
Both United stars got on the scoresheet in Thursday’s dramatic 4-3 away win at Wolves, Mainoo scoring his maiden Premier League goal in the 97th minute.
Hojlund is thankful to have the teenager in his side and says the squad’s breakthrough stars have made sure to keep in touch with one another away from the pitch.
United captain Bruno Fernandes reportedly turned down a mega-money offer from Saudi Arabia in January.
Record says the Portugal star was contacted by Saudi Pro League leaders Al-Hilal, who are managed by former Sporting Lisbon boss Jorge Jesus.

The 29-year-old, who was given the armabnd full-time over the summer, does not see his United contract expire until 2026. There are hints that Al-Hilal could return for Fernandes in the summer, the report adds.

headline: Manchester United showed just what Erik ten Hag wanted in West Ham win
body: Man Utd secured their easiest home win of the season in the Premier League as they beat West Ham 3-0 at Old Trafford.
A clinical touch

On the balance of play it's fair to say Manchester United didn't deserve to win this game 3-0. But for the first time this season, they are starting to show the clinical edge that can sometimes mark out the very best sides.

West Ham had almost twice as many shots as United and some very good chances, but they weren't efficient in front of goal and Erik ten Hag's side were. It's a ruthless side of the game we haven't seen enough this season but which is beginning to come to the fore at a valuable point of the campaign.

United have scored 15 goals in their last five games and although two of those were against teams from League One and League Two, they also scored twice against Tottenham, four times at Wolves and now three against West Ham.

The finishes produced by Rasmus Hojlund for the first and Alejandro Garnacho for the third showed how important players who can put chances away are. Maybe it's a learning curve for young players, but this side were guilty of missing too many chances earlier in the season. Now they are capitalising more often than not.

Hojlund is leading that change. His goal to open the scoring on Sunday came out of nothing. He worked the space for himself and finished brilliantly. It set an example that Garnacho followed and although this wasn't a brilliant United performance the scoreline was convincing, which has rarely been the case this season.

On countless occasions this season Ten Hag has complained about the lack of a clinical edge in his team. He even did so after the draw against Tottenham last month. He told his team they "weren't clinical enough" after the 3-3 draw with Galatasaray in Istanbul that all but ended their Champions League campaign. Finally, it looks like the message is getting through.
Martinez concerns

There were shades of Virgil van Dijk's defending against Moussa Sissoko with the way Lisandro Martinez saw off a dangerous West Ham counter early in the second half. In 2019 Van Dijk was lauded for allowing Sissoko to shoot and instead blocking off the pass to Son Heung-min, who was clearly the more dangerous player.

Martinez did exactly the same here and although he didn't touch the ball, he knew how decisive his decision-making had been when he turned to the crowd to celebrate. It was Emerson Palmieri with the chance, seizing on a loose touch from Harry Maguire to race clear in a two-on-one.
But Martinez blocked the square pass to Jarrod Bowen and forced Emerson to go on his own. His finish was befitting of a full-back who had clearly been desperate to pass.

Martinez's absence has perhaps been the most important of all for United this season, so the sight of him hobbling off in the second half left a cloud over the victory. Ten Hag's post-match diagnosis didn't sound at all encouraging.
Casemiro's contribution

Hojlund will rightly take the plaudits for the brilliance of the goal that gave United the lead, but it wouldn't have been possible without the aggressive, instinctive play that Casemiro displayed throughout last season.

The Brazilian has been a disappointment this season but since returning from an ankle injury he's shown signs of rediscovering his best form. He played a key role in the opener. He looked second favourite to reach the loose ball from Kurt Zouma's clearing header but read the game well and showed good strength to get in front of James Ward-Prowse and beat Tomas Soucek to the ball.

Casemiro made up 10 yards in very little time to slide in and touch the ball to Hojlund. And although what followed was all down to the Dane, the contribution of United's holding midfielder shouldn't be overlooked given it felt like the kind of thing he wasn't doing enough of in the first few months of the season.
Mainoo v Phillips

Kalvin Phillips made the move from Manchester City to West Ham to play the regular football he needs to cement his place in England's Euro 2024 squad, so with Gareth Southgate's assistant Steve Holland watching on at Old Trafford, the midfielder would have been disappointed to have been dropped after one game by his new club.

Phillips gave away the penalty from which Bournemouth scored in midweek and was immediately benched by David Moyes. As a former Leeds and current City player, he had to warm-up in front of the Stretford End, which went as you would expect it to.

It's been a tricky 18 months or so for Phillips since leaving his boyhood club and he was never fancied by Pep Guardiola at the Etihad. He has been a favourite of Southgate's, but his place in the England squad must be under pressure. Several youngsters are making a push for the squad and 18-year-old Kobbie Mainoo has to be at the forefront. He is now just 16 games into his senior club career but must be on Southgate's radar, especially with Ghana trying to convince the Stockport-born midfielder to represent the country of his parents.
Maguire's return

Raphael Varane's fitness record speaks for itself at United and in a way the World Cup winner had a good run starting six successive games without picking up another issue, before being benched against West Ham.

That was his longest run of starts in a row in two years and shows how badly injuries have affected his time at the club and his ability to string a run of games together. He remains a superb centre-back, but he struggles to play twice a week, has already retired from international duty and has gone public with his complaints about the schedule.

He is going to need to be rested every now and again and with Maguire back fit it made sense to rotate here, especially given Varane had played at Wolves on Thursday night. Maguire's form this season has warranted more starts.

He defended well against the Hammers in the first half. He read the game superbly early on to get to the ball ahead of Bowen and then made a superb tackle later to block Mohammed Kudus, when he was about to play Ben Johnson into acres of space down the right.

There were a couple of shaky moments after the break, gifting a big chance to Emerson Palmieri at 1-0 and then allowing a ball to go over his head to let Bowen in at 2-0. He got away with both, however, and that is maybe the difference for Maguire at the moment.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund's Manchester United prediction is already starting to take shape
body: Youth was to the fore at Man United as they secured a second successive Premier League victory by beating West Ham 3-0 at Old Trafford.

For a football club as committed to youth development as Manchester United, the sight of three young players sitting arm-in-arm on the Old Trafford hoardings celebrating another goal was manor from heaven.

On a day when United commemorated the lives lost too soon in the Munich air disaster 66 years ago on Tuesday, the picture of Kobbie Mainoo, Alejandro Garnacho and Rasmus Hojlund beaming from ear-to-ear felt a fitting one. After Garnacho had scored the second of the afternoon against West Ham, the 18-year-old, 19-year-old and 21-year-old had been responsible for United's last three goals in less than an hour of football. Just for good measure, Garnacho added a third on the day.

It was an image to the promise of youth. Mainoo was the hero at Molineux on Thursday night, Hojlund is the birthday boy who is showing the value of confidence and Garnacho the one who looks like a star, a flying winger in the mould of so many before him at Old Trafford.

After the thrilling finale at Wolves in the week, Hojlund spoke about wanting to define an era with the other young players at the club. In a season that has proven to be more difficult than anyone expected, it is the spirit of youth that has given United some hope and it is a cohort being led by the Mancunian, the Dane and the Argentine.

There was an almost inevitable lull for Mainoo after his heroics of the previous week. He was solid again without the spectacular contributions he carved out against Newport and Wolves. But he is undoubtedly a fixture in this side now despite his tender years. This was his ninth start in a row.

Garnacho is on double that and after 18 successive starts, his reputation as a thrilling forward only capable of influencing games off the bench is a thing of the past. He is thriving on the right and although he wasn't at his best in the first half against West Ham, he worked space well for his first goal after the break and the finish for his second was calmly done. He is becoming a more consistent threat.

But it was Hojlund who set the tone for this win on the day he celebrated his 21st birthday. It's just under six weeks since the cathartic release of his first Premier League goal on Boxing Day and that really was the start of something. He can't stop scoring now.

His goal on Thursday night showed the instincts of a penalty box predator, bundling the ball home by any means possible, but in his short United career, he has already shown an eye for the spectacular as well. His 10th goal of the season in all competitions fit that description.

He picked up Casemiro's interception 22 yards from goal, threatened to go on his left, chopped inside Nayef Aguerd onto his weaker foot and struck a rasping low drive into the bottom corner. It was a slick bit of play, much slicker than the unsteady celebration that followed, although by full-time it wasn't the celebration United fans were talking about.

It was a key goal, however. West Ham were the better side in the first half and United barely threatened. By full-time the Hammers had racked up 21 shots to United's 12 and would have been wondering how they had lost the game so convincingly. The infectious enthusiasm of youth was one reason.

Hojlund gave United a lead they scarcely deserved but badly needed and Garnacho sealed the deal. They built on the momentum Mainoo had handed them on Thursday night. As a performance, this wasn't as good as that glimpsed at Molineux. But it was another victory delivered by the youngsters who might just be good enough to define an era at Old Trafford.

headline: 'Personal disaster' - Manchester United give Lisandro Martinez update
body: Lisandro Martinez may have suffered a season-ending injury after he was forced off in the win against West Ham.
Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag has described Lisandro Martinez's apparent knee injury as a "personal disaster".
Martinez's knee buckled under the weight of West Ham defender Vladimir Coufal in the 66th minute of United's 3-0 Premier League win at Old Trafford and he was forced off in the 71st minute.
Ten Hag was unable to provide a specific prognosis on the injury but said it was "very bad" and Martinez was "very sad".
"I can't say, it doesn't look good so there's a big concern, but we have to wait for the coming days what the diagnosis is then we can tell you more.

"We do everything to get the right diagnosis to see what the damage is. He is very sad, very disappointed. We all feel really with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is.
"But for the team, also it is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."
Martinez returned from a four-month lay-off with a foot injury against Tottenham three weeks ago and he started in United's recent wins at Newport County and Wolves.

The 26-year-old sustained a metatarsal injury in the Europa League quarter-final first leg draw with Sevilla in April that ended his first season at United early. He required a second round of surgery in September.
Martinez's injury blemished one of the most comfortable afternoons of United's season as they won by a three-goal margin for the first time in a home league game since May.
Ten Hag is not getting carried away, though. "It's only one game, so don't celebrate this too much. We don't have reasons in this moment to do it but for today we are pleased with it.

"But you need routines to get consistent performances. So you have to make decisions in a split second and when every time you have to swap your team, you have to swap your centre halves, swap your back four, positioning the right full-back to the left full-back and swap back again, and all those adjustments, all those rules and principles.

"It's about looking at each other, taking the right decisions. Top football is about the right details. When detail doesn't work, you concede goals then you're following the facts and we've had that too much this season.

"I'm not telling you we are there where we want but you see the potential. But you can only work on the potential when the team is available and when certain positions are not available you have to be creative.

"We have times in the season where every time we have to adapt to put an XI out and now in this moment, we don't have. But then the injury is coming from Licha Martinez so I hope we are not going back in such a process, we want to stay away from it.

"We want to work on the team. And I know it's not about 11 players. It's about 15 or 16 players. I hope we can keep them all fit and I think then we can still achieve a lot in this season. In this Premier League, everyone is killing everyone and the process is going from final to final."

headline: Martinez, Malacia, Mount, Wan-Bissaka - Manchester United injury news and return dates
body: Lisandro Martinez picked up a knee injury for Man Utd after impressing during their 3-0 win over West Ham in the Premier League on Sunday afternoon

Manchester United are sweating on Lisandro Martinez after their World Cup-winning defender picked up a nasty-looking knee injury against West Ham on Sunday afternoon. United won the game 3-0 at Old Trafford with Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho (2) settling the scores in a comprehensive victory.

However, chalking up three points was not without concern. Martinez - who impressed at the back after stepping up his return from a previous setback - had to be taken off on 70 minutes after clutching his knee. Erik ten Hag said in his post-match press conference the early signs do not look good for the Argentine.
Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Tyrell Malacia, Mason Mount and Anthony Martial were all unavailable for selection. Here, we provide our latest round-up from the treatment table at Carrington;
Injury: Knee
Return date: TBC

What Ten Hag has said: "I can't say [how long], but it doesn't look good so there's a big concern, but we have to wait for the coming days what the diagnosis is then we can tell you more. We do everything to get that diagnosis to see what the damage is.

"He's very sad, very disappointed. We all really feel with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster, when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is. For the team, also, it is really bad because he brings us a lot."
Injury: Unspecified
Possible return date: February 11 vs Aston Villa (A)
Wan-Bissaka picked up an unspecified injury before the FA Cup win over League Two opponents Newport County and has not returned to action since. He was among four players absent against West Ham.
Injury: Knee
Predicted return date: February 2024

What Ten Hag has said: "Tyrell Malacia had surgery, but he will return in quite short notice. From the New Year onwards, he can be available. We are very happy with it. Also, the others, they are working very hard to return as soon as possible."
Injury: Calf
Possible return date: February 11 vs Aston Villa (A)
What Ten Hag has said: "Mason Mount will return, but take a little longer."
Injury: Knee
Predicted return date: April 2024

What United have said: Anthony Martial has completed successful surgery to address a groin complaint and will be out of action for about 10 weeks as he rehabilitates. We wish Anthony a speedy recovery.

headline: Manchester United player ratings as Rasmus Hojlund and Lisandro Martinez very good vs West Ham
body: Man United beat West Ham in the Premier League at Old Trafford and here are how Erik ten Hag's players rated.
Manchester United leapfrogged West Ham United and jumped into the Premier League's top six with a 3-0 win over David Moyes' side on Sunday afternoon.
United went in front when Rasmus Hojlund scored for the fourth game in a row with a fine first-half finish. Alejandro Garnacho added a second early in the second period when he cut inside to score.

The winger sealed the points in the closing stages with his second of the afternoon and United's third. The only downside for Erik ten Hag was an injury to Lisandro Martinez with the defender forced off in the final quarter.
Andre Onana: Made a good early save from Edson Alvarez's ricochet and dealt dependably with other attempts on target. 7
Diogo Dalot: Pitted against Mohammed Kudus, who switched flanks, and fared well in a tight duel. Brilliantly covered for Harry Maguire's mistake to deny Jarrod Bowen. 8
Harry Maguire: Back in the starting XI for the first time in almost two months and produced one of his strongest performances of the season until he let Emerson Palmieri in. Did likewise for Bowen. 6
Lisandro Martinez: Different partner but same Martinez. Often the defender in the way of a pass or a shot. Had to come off after his knee buckled under the weight of Vladimir Coufal. 8
Luke Shaw: Not as probing in the final third as he has been of late but defensively excellent again before and after Kudus switched to the right flank. 7
Casemiro: Not as influential as in midweek but his pressing led to the opening goal and he shielded United vigilantly as they defended their 2-0 advantage. 7
Kobbie Mainoo: Another tidy performance in front of England assistant manager Steve Holland. Earned a standing ovation and congratulations from teammates when he came off. 7
Alejandro Garnacho: Pocketed by Emerson Palmieri in the first half but wriggled out of it to score early in the second, via a deflection. Then scored again to kill the game. 8
Bruno Fernandes: Drew a vigilant stop from Alphonse Areola and played the ball to Garnacho for the second goal. Could have scored himself but for an errant touch. 7
Marcus Rashford: Embarked on bright bursts with and without the ball and had some shooting opportunities but not on target today. 6
Rasmus Hojlund: Broke double figures in the goalscoring form with his best goal yet for United. Now has four goals in his last four Premier League games. 9
Subs
Scott McTominay: Assisted Garnacho. 7
Raphael Varane: Helped United keep a clean sheet. 7
Victor Lindelof: First game in two months. 6
Antony: Late cameo. 6
Manager
Made one change to rest Varane and United kept a clean sheet, despite West Ham's proactive play. Another good day in the dugout. 8

headline: Diogo Dalot hints at severity of Lisandro Martinez injury amid Manchester United concern
body: Manchester United's 3-0 win over West Ham United was tarnished by a potentially serious knee injury for Lisandro Martinez
Manchester United defender Diogo Dalot has sent a heartfelt message to Lisandro Martinez after the Argentine suffered another injury concern.

Martinez was forced off shortly after the hour mark after his knee buckled following a challenge from West Ham United defender Vladimir Coufal. It sparks another injury concern for Erik ten Hag after the former Ajax man endured a four-month layoff after sustaining a foot injury against Tottenham Hotspur.

The incident soured a complete United performance as they brushed aside the East London club. Alejandro Garnacho was the pick of the bunch with a brace as Rasmus Hojlund topped his 21st birthday celebrations with a goal.

Images show Martinez in agony after being left in a heap following the Czech Republic international's challenge. And Dalot was among the players to express support amid the anxious wait for the 26-year-old's diagnosis.

"Your pain is our pain. You will be back soon my brother," he wrote in an Instagram story post. Speaking after the triumph, the United boss offered a bleak outlook surrounding the severity of the issue.
"I can't say, it doesn't look good so there's a big concern, but we have to wait for the coming days what the diagnosis is then we can tell you more," he said.

"We do everything to get the right diagnosis to see what the damage is. He is very sad, very disappointed. We all feel really with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is.
"But for the team, also it is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."

headline: Manchester United are doing what Rasmus Hojlund said they would after win vs West Ham
body: Wreaths were placed on the Old Trafford pitch in memory of the victims of the Munich air disaster ahead of the 66th anniversary. The latest batch of captivating Manchester United fledglings are starting to spread their wings.

Rasmus Hojlund only spoke of his hope he and his fellow rookies "can set an era for the club and be here many years together" on Thursday night. Here three of them were, sat together, posing in victory.

Alejandro Garnacho mimicked West Ham winger Mohammed Kudus's signature celebration by sitting on the advertising hoarding and facing the pitch. He was joined by Hojlund and Kobbie Mainoo. United fans will hope to be watching and talking about their generation for several years.
United-bred duo Garnacho and Mainoo are still in their teens but Hojlund turned 21 today. His goal on Boxing Day feels like a coming of age and he now has four in his past four Premier League starts.

Mainoo, substituted for the first time since December, earned a standing ovation and compliments from Luke Shaw and Marcus Rashford on his way to the touchline. Erik ten Hag offered a congratulatory pat on the head.

Garnacho gained a chant days after his United debut as a 17-year-old on the night of the FA Youth Cup triumph in 2022. As the frontman, Hojlund deserves a backing band and the Stockport-born Mainoo can expect to enter United's tome of a songbook soon.

The youth were underpinned by the veterans. Casemiro's urgent press made Hojlund's goal possible and, bar one major lapse, Harry Maguire was commanding on his return to the starting XI for the first time in nearly eight weeks.

Maguire relinquished the captain's armband six months ago but is still an authoritative figure. The applause for one interception had barely subsided and he was ushering Lisandro Martinez further forward, acknowledging his superior distribution in the middle third.

When Maguire erred and let Jarrod Bowen in, Diogo Dalot rushed across to hurl his body in the way of the ball, a goal-saving block that brought United fans to their feet. The ball was still live when Maguire thanked him. Dalot has firmly cemented his status as starting right-back and, not for the first time, it has coincided with Aaron Wan-Bissaka going AWOL.

United fans' chants of 'Argentina' began at the Boleyn Ground in support of David Beckham back in August 1998 and one of the loudest renditions came in response to Martinez's tangle with Vladimir Coufal. Martinez's enforced withdrawal was the only negative. Ten Hag admitted it was a "personal disaster".

After squandering two-goal leads at Newport and Wolverhampton, there was an elusive third goal that ensured a rare day devoid of drama. United went 3-0 up for only the third time this term. The last time it happened in a home league fixture was last May.

Ten Hag and one of his predecessors, David Moyes, carried the wreaths when both teams emerged from the tunnel. A besuited Moyes, with the Manchester coat of arms stitched onto his blazer, visited the Manchesterplatz site in Munich when he was United manager in 2014. Supporters present appreciated that.

In West Ham colours, Moyes looked understandably disappointed by their profligacy in the first half and it continued early into the second. Emerson Palmieri seized on Maguire's hesitancy and looked to pass when he had to shoot. He only threatened those in the Scoreboard End. A minute later, Garnacho wriggled out of Palmieri's pocket and scored.

There were high fives and hugs all round for Hojlund, as well as a chest bump from Maguire to mark his 23rd-minute opener. Hojlund has now broken double figures for United goals and his 10th was his most singular. The Dane has scored some great goals and his potential to be a great goalscorer is more apparent with every game.

Hojlund had the confidence to deceive the West Ham defenders and switch the ball to his weaker right foot. He wellied the ball in as though it was his strongest. Whilst players joined the throng, Ten Hag had stuffed his hands back into his pockets. He is nearing vindication with the £72million striker.

Steve Holland, Gareth Southgate's assistant, was in the directors' box and nattering with the United football director John Murtough before kick-off. Five England internationals started across both sides but the one Holland had to have cast his eye over carefully was Mainoo. The 18-year-old drew applause in the 21st minute for a smart shimmy that deceived Kudus before setting Garnacho on his way.

Another England midfielder, Kalvin Phillips, was promptly dropped by Moyes after a chastening debut against Bournemouth in midweek. Phillips's substitute status did not spare the former Leeds and Manchester City midfielder from the Stretford End giving him grief during an early warm-up. Phillips was a good enough sport to engage in the repartee. Then he was robbed of the ball for Garnacho's second goal.
Phillips was still seated when Garnacho, Hojlund and Mainoo sat down.

headline: Erik ten Hag gets brutal warning as Sir Jim Ratcliffe plans sweeping Manchester United changes
body: Investment from INEOS founder Sir Jim Ratcliffe has been formalised - subject to Premier League ratification - and changes have been made behind the scenes

Gary Neville reckons Erik ten Hag might need to usurp Aston Villa or Tottenham in order to keep his job. Change is on the horizon for Manchester United behind the scenes with investment from Sir Jim Ratcliffe rubber-stamped on Christmas Eve - although that deal remains subject to Premier League ratification.

There has been precious little to celebrate at Old Trafford and beyond on the pitch this season. However, now the injury woes have started to subside, United have won their last two matches to move up to sixth-place with goals from Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho (2) doing the damage against West Ham.

Five teams from England - rather than the usual four - could be awarded Champions League spots next campaign and that opens the door up for improved United moving forward. However, with Villa and Tottenham four and six points above them respectively, there is work to do.

Speaking about Ten Hag and his position, Neville told Sky Sports: "That's the biggest decision the new ownership will have to make in the next few months. They'll bring in a sporting director, because there's not one already, but whether they keep the manager is the one everyone will be looking out for come the end of the season."

Neville added: "Roy [Keane] said it that fifth is the best I think they could possibly do. One of those teams, Aston Villa or Tottenham, would have to slip up because I don't think they're anywhere near Arsenal, City and Liverpool.

"Those teams are gone. For United and Ten Hag - if he wants to continue here - he'll have to impress those above him before the end of the season. INEOS and Sir Jim Ratcliffe, they'll go into that club and be disruptive, they have to be, so I think that they're all under pressure.
"They need to deliver, so much money has been spent on that squad. They've underachieved so much this season that it's incredible."

headline: Manchester United might have to try and sell at least 11 players this summer
body: Man United need to clear the decks in the 2024 summer transfer window and begin the process of trying to avoid mistakes of yesteryear.
If Sir Jim Ratcliffe corrects just one department at Manchester United this forthcoming summer, it has to be the recruitment department.

For far too long, United have been guilty of over-spending on players, courtesy of poor strategic planning and rash decision-making. As part of their minority investment at Old Trafford, INEOS have secured management of the club's football operations, meaning they will oversee all aspects of recruitment.

INEOS, of course, have acted swiftly to try and lay the foundations for a brighter future on that particular front, swooping for Omar Berrada, who has been installed as the club's new CEO, from Manchester City. He has already warned about the dangers of paying over the odds for players - something United have been guilty of time after time.

The £85.5million acquisition of Antony from Ajax in September 2022 is a prime example. The art of perfecting recruitment is a two-way system and United have not mastered it in recent years. They have been guilty of stock-piling players, often allowing them to run down their contracts and leave for free, or selling them for minimal fees when the likes of Liverpool and Manchester City have commanded respectable fees for their unwanted stars.

Though they have played their part for United this season, the club's failure to offload both Harry Maguire and Scott McTominay last summer are prime examples of their failure to trim the squad and command hefty transfer fees. United cannot afford to repeat such errors ahead of 2024/25, and it is unlikely that INEOS will allow them to.
This forthcoming summer's transfer window promises to be one of the most intriguing United have faced in years. The eyes of the world will be on Old Trafford to see what impact INEOS have.

If they are serious about taking United back to the top, they need to significantly improve the club's ability to trade in the transfer market. Looking ahead to the summer, the Reds have a whole host of players on their books who need moving on permanently.

Focusing primarily on those who will be under contract at the beginning of next season, you can argue that a minimum of 11 players need selling, both for the benefit of the club and each individual's career. Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Victor Lindelof have both had their contracts extended until June 2025, meaning United have avoided the risk of losing them for free this summer.

United plan to recruit a first-choice right-back ahead of next season, meaning either Diogo Dalot or Wan-Bissaka will need moving on. Dalot has a higher ceiling, meaning it would make sense to cash in on Wan-Bissaka this summer, with the next transfer window representing United's last chance to try and secure a respectable fee for him.
The same can be said for Lindelof. United want to sign a new centre-back this summer, meaning the Swede's game time could be reduced even further, resulting in his valuation dropping.

Other United defenders are not safe from being sold, either. Will Fish, under contract until 2025, with the option to extend for a further year, is currently on a second loan spell at Hibernian in as many seasons, meaning, with all due respect, he is never likely to make the grade at Old Trafford and become a regular under Erik ten Hag.

Brandon Williams and Alvaro Fernandez both have clauses within their contracts for additional one-year options to be triggered, meaning they could then pave the way for potential offers to come United's way, so long as suitors have already declared interest. The deal which saw Benfica sign Fernandez includes an obligation to buy if he starts 50 per cent of matches and they will pay €6m plus €3m in potential add-ons. There will still be an option to buy if the obligation isn't triggered.
Hannibal Mejbri and Donny van de Beek both departed on loan last month, joining Sevilla and Eintracht Frankfurt respectively. Each deal could be made permanent.
Though Hannibal offered flashes of his class earlier this term, he is unlikely to have a long-term future at Old Trafford. Van de Beek needs moving off the books as soon as possible.

In forward areas, Facundo Pellistri and Jadon Sancho departed on loan in the January window, potentially ending their hopes of long-term futures in M16. Sancho had been frozen out by Ten Hag since September after a public fallout.

If both players impress during their respective loans at Granada and Borussia Dortmund, this summer would represent an opportunity for United to cash in. The sales of both players would almost certainly see them record losses, though.

Mason Greenwood is still under contract at Old Trafford, meaning United need to actively try and get him off the books permanently this summer. Several clubs in Spain, including current loan club Getafe, have been linked with signing him.

Omari Forson may also be sold for a fee if United tie him down to a new contract. He is out-of-contract this summer, but the Reds, in the past, have tied a player down to a new deal and then sold them at the next available juncture.

headline: I watched Manchester United beat West Ham and saw a glimpse into a bright future
body: Here are the moments you might have missed from Man United's 3-0 win over West Ham United in the Premier League on Sunday afternoon.

Two goals from Alejandro Garnacho, both of which came in the second half, and one from Rasmus Hojlund prior to the break gave the Reds their biggest home league win of the season. United have now won each of their last two league outings, scoring seven goals in the process.

Though the victory suggested United had everything their own way, West Ham had the better of the chances in the first half. They also spurned a golden opportunity to draw level moments before Garnacho made it 2-0 at the start of the second period.

Nevertheless, United were full value for their victory over the course of the 90 minutes, inspired by eye-catching displays from Hojlund and Garnacho. The duo, particularly the latter, caused no shortage of problems for David Moyes' side, who had arrived at Old Trafford one point ahead of the Reds in the standings. Below, MEN Sport has highlighted some of the moments you may not have spotted from Sunday's encounter at Old Trafford.

Ahead of kick-off at Old Trafford, former United striker Robin van Persie was spotted back in familiar surroundings. The former Netherlands international spent three years in M16, scoring 58 goals in 105 appearances in all competitions between 2012 and 2015.

Such was the level of success he enjoyed during his time at the club, it was hardly surprising to see so many United fans sat in front of the directors' box asking him for a picture and his autograph. Van Persie kindly agreed to those requests and spent a few moments engaging with supporters. He was also in attendance at Old Trafford for the 3-2 win over Aston Villa on Boxing Day.

Though United took a slender 1-0 lead into the half-time interval, their defenders had had to deal with more than what West Ham's had in the first half. Either side of Hojlund's opener, United's back-four and keeper Andre Onana were called into action.

With 35 minutes on the clock, West Ham attempted to work the ball into the left channel of the penalty area with Emerson Palmieri latching onto a clever pass from Mohammed Kudus. But before Emerson even had chance to lift his head in the hope of picking out a man in a white shirt, Lisandro Martinez was across to greet him.

The Argentine arrived on the scene in the blink of an eye, making an excellent challenge to put the ball into touch. As soon as he was back on his feet, Diogo Dalot was slapping his flesh in a show of appreciation and celebration.

Dalot produced a tackle at Molineux on Thursday night that resulted in Raphael Varane, Onana and Martinez coming over and celebrating it like a goal. This may have been Martinez's way of returning the favour.

As Harry Maguire gave the ball away in a dangerous area, few inside Old Trafford would have anticipated celebrating a second United goal a few moments later. But after the Reds had got themselves up the pitch quickly, the majority of those inside M16 were on their feet.

Garnacho provided the all-important knockout blow, seeing a deflected effort fly past replacement West Ham goalkeeper Lukasz Fabianski. He wheeled over to the far side to celebrate the adjoining corners between the Stretford End and the Sir Alex Ferguson Stand.

Once in position, he perched himself on the edge of the advertising hoardings and was soon joined by Kobbie Mainoo and Hojlund, with the duo sitting either side of him. Each donning huge smiles, they put their arms around each other for a few seconds, no doubt savouring the smiles and happy faces all around them. We could be seeing the same celebration on show time and time again in the coming years.

After converting his second goal of the afternoon, Garnacho ran in the direction of where he had celebrated his first. Just like on the previous occasion, the youngster perched himself on the advertising hoardings.

With Mainoo off the field of play by this juncture, there was no chance of his first celebration being replicated in full. However, after being mobbed by his teammates, Hojlund embraced his fellow forward and gave him a small kiss on the cheek. It was another moment that highlighted the togetherness and spirit within the squad.

headline: Manchester United have found their next Paul Pogba in the academy
body: Man Utd youngster Kobbie Mainoo is making exceptional progress and he's already been likened to Paul Pogba.

Making comparisons between established and young players is often not helpful but it's inevitable. Kobbie Mainoo has been likened to Paul Pogba and his performance for Manchester United's Under-21s against Salford City in October intensified the comparisons.

Mainoo recorded two assists and he sprayed some beautiful passes under the floodlights. His movement was reminiscent of Pogba's and the MEN's match report from that game said: "The midfielder has outgrown academy football and his talent is needed in the first-team."
Mainoo was carefully handled after his return from injury and he featured for the U21s in a handful of games, but it was only a matter of time before Erik ten Hag gave him opportunities.
The 18-year-old has been exceptional since breaking into the first-team this season and he's now one of the first names on the team sheet, which is the ultimate compliment.

Speaking last year shortly after his senior debut, someone who is close to Mainoo confidently said he would play for England and he now has an outside chance of making the Three Lions squad for this summer's European Championship after making just 12 appearances for United.
His progress has been remarkable and he possesses all the attributes to become a world-class talent, just like Pogba did when emerging from the club's academy in the late 2000s.
Pogba left on a free transfer to join Juventus in the summer of 2012 after failing to agree a new contract when it might have been advisable to build a team around him.

The Frenchman returned to Old Trafford in 2016 but his second stint wasn't a success and supporters do not remember his time in a red shirt fondly. There is no chance of Mainoo leaving on a free transfer but there is a feeling that the team should be built around him.
United have developed another special talent and he has the temperament and talent to succeed. Mainoo is understood to be quiet, likeable and kept well-grounded by his parents.

There were character issues with Pogba during his time at United and such problems with Mainoo seem highly unlikely to happen. He has the talent to eclipse Pogba's legacy in Manchester and comparisons between himself and Frenkie de Jong have also been merited.
Mainoo has operated as a deep-lying midfielder in the majority of his senior appearances, but those who know him best have suggested his long-term future will be as a No.8.
Adding goals to his game has been privately identified as an area for improvement and his two goals in two games against Newport County and Wolves show he's progressing.
Mainoo's matchwinner at Molineux gets better every time you watch it. It was a moment of individual brilliance and Rasmus Hojlund described him as a 'generational talent' after the game.

Erik ten Hag also gave him a glowing assessment. "I think very quickly I saw him," Ten Hag said. "I think last autumn I saw him for the first time and at that moment I thought he was playing a little bit too comfortable. I saw him playing in the U21s, he should be much more dominant.
"We pushed him a lot on that side, by pushing him in the training and you see he makes such good progress and he is almost progressing from game to game.
"And of course, it's wonderful to see and I hope he stays calm like he is, as he did with his goal as well. He is determined, he is a good character and I hope he keeps going with this progress."
In a separate interview with MUTV, Ten Hag added: "What he did was great, no doubt about that. He's a calm person and it looks like he grows from game to game, so hopefully he keeps this going.
"I will push and support him, but he has to do it. He has great abilities and in the future, he can be a great player. Today, we have seen it, but also in the last couple of games."
Ten Hag has a strong record of developing talent and Mainoo is at the right place to take his game to another level.
His potential is frightening and a new star from Carrington has been born. He could be everything Pogba was supposed to be for United.

headline: Erik ten Hag admits Manchester United 'headaches' and makes Champions League admission
body: Latest Manchester United news as Erik ten Hag looks ahead to United's Premier League clash against West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday
Erik ten Hag admits that Manchester United's thrilling 4-3 win over Wolves on Thursday gave "some headaches".

Goals from Marcus Rashford and Rasmus Hojlund gave United a deserved 2-0 lead against Gary O'Neil's side before a controversial penalty decision was converted by Pablo Sarabia to make it 2-1. United then restored their two-goal cushion through Scott McTominay with a deft header.

But the hosts fought back through Max Kilman and Pedro Neto to make it 3-3 before Kobbie Mainoo's superb finish in the 97th minute sealed all three points. And Ten Hag admits the clash at Molineux should never have been a contest when United put themselves in a commanding position at half-time.

"Yeah, we were, of course, very pleased with the win," he said via the club's website. "It was a match with many stories and we are pleased with our levels - in the first hour, I would say, especially the first 45 minutes.

"But after that, we should have killed the game and we didn’t. We let them return but then the team showed character and got the win, so I’m happy for our fans. I would say it was a thriller, I think. For the neutral spectator, it was also very nice to watch this game. But for a manager, it gives some headaches."

United take on West Ham at Old Trafford on Sunday with both teams separated by just a single point. Ten Hag acknowledged the West Ham fixture will be a tricky one, with the Hammers coming into the game with a point to prove.

"Yes but it’s always about us," he said. "I always have a lot of respect and I already mentioned the qualities, the positives from West Ham United. But it’s about us - where we deliver our standards, when we bring it on the pitch, when we play as a team, then we will win the game no matter what.

"So it’s all about us, they take responsibility as a team to win the game because the fans need the win and we need the three points." And the Dutchman admits his team cannot afford to drop too many more points as they sit nine points off the top four.

"It will not be decisive for the end of the season but in the Premier League, [there are] seven or eight teams competing for those four [Champions League] positions so we can’t give points away," Ten Hag added.

"You need every point and you have to fight for every point because the points will be more expensive when you go to the end of the season, so we have to make sure, to put us in the right position in the month of February, we have to win on Sunday."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund is making Manchester United's summer transfer decision for them
body: Man Utd will look to sign a couple of forwards in the summer transfer window, and Rasmus Hojlund could influence those plans.
Erik ten Hag admits he wanted to sign another striker in the January transfer window. Rasmus Hojlund is at least easing those concerns for now.
The Danish forward took a while to adapt to the physicality of the Premier League, but now he looks right at home with goals in three successive matches.

What is most pleasing is that the last two goals in particular have been typical predatory finishes, with Hojlund in the right place at the right time to bundle the ball in from close range. He won't get much credit for those goals, but they are exactly the type United haven't been scoring in recent years.
OPINION: Mainoo has done something no other player has done under Ten Hag

Hojlund has also suffered from a lack of consistent support from his teammates so far this season, and it is no surprise his output has picked up at a time when a number of key players returned to the squad. His goal at Wolves, for example, would not have been possible without Luke Shaw in the side.

There is real excitement surrounding Hojlund at the moment, and there is real intrigue about how good he can become after such a promising run of form. Although the answer may intrigue supporters, the club's transfer committee is in dire need of finding it before the summer transfer market opens.

United are in the market for at least two forwards this summer, with Anthony Martial, Jadon Sancho, and Mason Greenwood all set to leave. Facundo Pellistri could also be sold, and Amad might need another loan move too. The jury is also very much out on Antony.
Hojlund's form in the closing months of the season will influence the type of striker United look to add to their squad, as they consider both short-term solutions and long-term additions.
There is still an argument United need another experienced option to help ease the burden on Hojlund, though signing a player currently in their prime would not be good for the player's development.

Likewise, there is also a danger of signing another relatively inexperienced and raw striker, because it could be doubling their problem rather than halving it. This would also cause the issue of trying to develop two players at the same time, something that can't really be done when they only play with one central attacker.

In an ideal world, United would add another experienced option in the same mould as previous signings Zlatan Ibrahimovic or Edinson Cavani this summer, though perhaps one who is slightly younger than those two were when they arrived, respectively.
This would give United a viable alternative to Hojlund in the forward line, but at the same time, they would not have to promise them a key role and regular starts either.

It seems like the best plan for United to reinforce their options this summer, yet in order for it to work, it relies on the Danish forward maintaining his recent level of improvement until the end of the campaign.

Based on what we have seen in recent weeks, it certainly seems a possibility, and with the United side replenished by so many returning players, he finally has the service he has been missing for so long.
Hojlund doesn't need replacing; he needs support.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo is helping Manchester United forget their recruitment mistake
body: The feel-good story in a bad season thus far for Man United is Kobbie Mainoo, who could help them have a successful run-in.
The Manchester United football director John Murtough was struggling for the appropriate word to summarise what he had just witnessed as he wandered up and down the tunnel at Molineux.

United have registered two 97th-minute winners this season, three victories have been secured beyond the 90th minute, they have recovered from 2-0 down to win 3-2 twice and all but four of their triumphs have been won by one goal. Even in a season where United's goal difference is still in minus numbers, there has been more drama than in a West End play.

When Erik ten Hag was almost on his knees against Brentford, Scott McTominay stood tall. Rasmus Hojlund was hunched over a seat and shaking his head in the dugout on Thursday night. Seconds later, he leapt into the arms of Harry Maguire.

As much as United strive to win games as comfortably as possible, winning in the manner that they did at Wolves is the best feeling in sport, never mind football. Kobbie Mainoo, at the age of 18, has followed in the footsteps of Steve Bruce, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, Paul Scholes et al. The good and the great have extended the legacy of Fergie Time.

Sir Alex Ferguson smiled broadly as the United away-dayers were kept at bay in the Steve Bull Stand. The incumbent United manager showed reasonable restraint as Mainoo jogged towards the moshpit on the far side.

Ten Hag was not the only one. Maguire eschewed the celebrations and pointed to his temple. United had folded at 3-1 and there was still time on the clock. That was on Ten Hag's mind at his post-match press conference.

"To be honest, I had mixed feelings" were Ten Hag's first words. He was vexed that United's performance had been undermined by preventable goals when they ought to have ended the night with their goal difference back in the positives.

Ten Hag has not been as strident in his criticism of United when they have won this season and he was perhaps emboldened by the sight of his strongest XI on the pitch in his 94th match in charge. United neared the standards they set last season.

Diogo Dalot, Raphael Varane and Lisandro Martinez rekindled their Latino alliance in defence, celebrating blocks, tackles and goal kicks. Casemiro was serenaded louder than ever this season, Marcus Rashford's finish had the finesse of some of his clinical strikes last season and United scored four goals in a Premier League match for only the second time under Ten Hag.
Ten Hag's constructive criticism in victory was a recurring theme in a successful 2022-23 campaign. "Good is not good enough" was his maxim. That has seldom been heard this season.

Those five words neatly summarised United at Wolves. The first half was their best 45 minutes of the season. Ten Hag argued the performance level extended to an hour. And still United squandered two two-goal leads and sieved three goals in 24 minutes.

It happened in Copenhagen and Istanbul. Mainoo did not start in either of those Champions League ties and, as raw as the 18-year-old is, United would have been in a better place had he avoided that deflating ankle injury in Houston against Real Madrid back in July. Mainoo is a diamond already sharp around the edges.

He is the feel-good story of a bad season thus far for United. It is just as well a Stockport-born academy graduate who still lives with his parents and switches his engine off in the main car park at Carrington has emerged as the long-term linchpin of United's midfield.

That was supposed to be Mason Mount, a £60million signing who has made nine starts in the last year and completed 90 minutes once. When Ten Hag was asked about Mount at Molineux, he spoke with a sombre tone that suggested United matchgoers could go another month without seeing him.
"He was struggling from the second game of the season," Ten Hag said. "He returned for a period and then picked up another injury, so of course that’s not great.
"That is very frustrating for him and I really feel for him. I really want to be there for him because he had such high expectations and I had high expectations."

Ten Hag added that "by the end of the season he can stay fit and fight his way into the team, or at least play a role in his team". The terrible troika of Michael Owen, Angel di Maria and Alexis Sanchez made a quicker impression than the current United number seven.

This season may well be a write-off for Mount, who had entered the last year of his contract at Chelsea. United have invested £60m to primarily foot his medical bills. Mount has been sidelined for a combined four months as a United player come next week.

Mount was always a dubious choice to pair with Casemiro. In hindsight, United should have invested completely in Mainoo's development, deferred a midfield recruit for another year and put the £60m towards Harry Kane. Easier said than done and the consensus this time last year was United required a dynamic midfielder. Mount never fit that bill but Mainoo does.

The theory that a player's reputation grows when they are out does not hold up with Mount. He struggled so much in his seven starts that no supporter or reporter has lamented his absence. Mainoo's was.
He has already left Murtough speechless.

headline: 'Will love to work with him' - Man United ace Kobbie Mainoo monitored ahead of huge potential switch
body: Man United midfielder Kobbie Mainoo stole the back page headlines on Friday morning after his incredibly late winner in the thrilling 4-3 victory over Wolverhampton Wanderers
Ghana FA chief Randy Abbey has stressed his association are working hard to convince Manchester United youngster Kobbie Mainoo to represent their country over England.

Mainoo is the talk of the Premier League at the moment after his stunning introduction to the United first team this season. Big things were expected of the teenager in pre-season however an unfortunate injury in the pre-season clash with Real Madrid in the US postponed his progress.
Eventually, the 18-year-old returned to the fold in the victory against Everton in November and earned plenty of new admirers. On Thursday night though he put in his first match-winning display.

The midfielder showed ability beyond his years as he curled home a fabulous winner to clinch a seven-goal thriller in the West Midlands. Talk is now beginning to turn towards potential international call-ups with Mainoo eligible to represent both England and Ghana.
