headline: Manchester United ‘make’ Kobbie Mainoo contract decision plus more transfer rumours
body: Mainoo has been one of Man United's standout players this season and might soon be rewarded for that.
Manchester United are reportedly set to hand Kobbie Mainoo a new and improved contract following his sensational performances this season.

The 18-year-old signed a fresh deal last February following his first-team debut a few weeks earlier. Mainoo has grown immensely since then and has become an important starting XI figure despite his tender age.

He grabbed his first Premier League goal with a dramatic 97th-minute winner against Wolves on Thursday after another impressive showing. Mainoo’s current deal runs until 2027 but could soon have his stay extended. The academy graduate will not be offered new terms before the summer in a bid to avoid distraction from his on-field form.

That’s according to the Daily Mail, which adds that Erik ten Hag now views him as an established first-team star and will hand Mainoo fresh terms at the end of the season to ward off any transfer interest.

Mainoo returned from a serious pre-season ankle injury in November to tally 12 senior appearances so far this term The teenager has started the last six Premier League matches, which stretches to eight when FA Cup ties are factored in.

Meanwhile, a report from HITC claims that Borussia Dortmund star Sebastian Haller was offered to United in January. Ten Hag revealed last week that the club had “no space” for new arrivals, even loans, amid Financial Fair Play concerns.

Haller, who has two goals in 14 outings, has Premier League experience having played for West Ham between 2019 and 2021. United, who have just lost Anthony Martial for two months after groin surgery, are after attacking reinforcements but would not have been able to afford 29-year-old Haller, no matter the price.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo and other Manchester United youngsters make encouraging dressing room decision
body: Mainoo has been in terrific form this season and is one Man Utd starlet to have made a mature off-field decision to enhance team spirit.
Rasmus Hojlund says Manchester United’s young players, including Kobbie Mainoo, have created a group chat between them on social media to build camaraderie within the dressing room.

Both United stars got on the scoresheet in Thursday’s dramatic 4-3 away win at Wolves, Mainoo scoring his maiden Premier League goal in the 97th minute. The midfielder has been one of the club’s standout performers this season despite being just 18 years old.
He is one of many United academy graduates to have made their debut under Erik ten Hag with the likes of Dan Gore, Omari Forson and Willy Kambwala all making their first-team bow this season.

Mainoo made his 60-minute debut almost 13 months ago and has flourished ever since, despite suffering a long-term ankle injury in pre-season. Hojlund is thankful to have the teenager in his side and says the squad’s breakthrough stars have made sure to keep in touch with one another away from the pitch.

“We enjoy spending time together,” £72m summer signing Hojlund said, as per the Mirror. “The young guys have a little group where we're chatting to each other and it's very cool to have other young players around the team.
“Hopefully we can set an era for the club and be here many years together. If you're good enough, you're old enough and I think that's a good thing. We're here for a reason.”
On Mainoo, he added: “You can see Kobbie’s composure. He is so relaxed on the ball. Now he's also starting to show that he has the scoring parts of his game as well. He's a complete player.”

Hojlund’s 22nd-minute goal at Molineux took his season tally to nine, of which three have come in the Premier League. The Dane did not get his first goal in the competition until Boxing Day but says his first strike has given him the confidence to score more.

“Of course, if you asked me, I would have loved to score my first goal in September or October,” he added. “I knew I could score goals. I had shown it in the Champions League and at my previous clubs.

“But, of course, opening the account means it’s like ‘Okay, I can do it’. It’s good to see. I hope we can keep going, keep the confidence in the team and keep providing for each other. I think that’s the key. We’re all being selfish when we have to but we also play for each other.”

headline: Manchester United have answered Gary Neville transfer question by unleashing new partnership
body: Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo played alongside each other for the first time in the Premier League when Man Utd overcame Wolves in their seven-goal thriller at Molineux

Manchester United have splashed out £400million-plus since Erik ten Hag stepped into their dugout last summer. However, perhaps his most important and transformative addition to the first-team squad is one that didn't cost a penny.

Kobbie Mainoo is the star that continues to rise at Old Trafford and beyond. There have been many false dawns in those barren post-Sir Alex Ferguson years - not to mention so much doom and gloom - but there are finally one or two shining lights at the end of the proverbial tunnel.

After watching Alejandro Garnacho take his first steps last season, Mainoo - another supremely talented academy graduate - has followed his path this campaign. The Stockport-born teenager remains a Premier League rookie and yet eight games into his senior career has become almost undroppable.

In doing so, the midfielder has helped United solve a transfer question Gary Neville asked this summer. Ultimately, though, the former captain turned TV pundit was not the only one to hold such concern.

United must not heap too much pressure on him - or Garnacho for that matter - but match-goers understand that better than anyone. Instead, they can revel in two no-longer-hidden gems who could well provide the cornerstone for the club to turn things around on the pitch.

Had things gone to plan, Mainoo would have been unleashed at an earlier juncture. Injury delayed his bow and by the time he made his mark on debut against Everton and other pre-Christmas games, Casemiro was unfortunately consigned to the Carrington treatment table himself.

The fit-again Brazilian powerhouse returned against Wolves and - over his 73-minute outing - United were able to address Neville and do something they too have been longing to do. The present and future combined in their engine room for the very first time.

Problems for United in midfield are long-standing. Ten Hag failed in his, at times, garishly public pursuit for Frenkie de Jong two summers ago, leading him to snap up an ageing Casemiro for £60million from Real Madrid in addition to four other players - including two loan deals - in that same position.
Casemiro was not the player United wanted last season. However, the 31-year-old was a better fit for the squad at that time, protecting the back four virtually on his own.

Question marks around his early-season form this campaign highlighted that United needed to make yet another move in that position. However, amid uncertainty and a lack of further conviction in the transfer market, a genuine and forward-thinking answer was right there in their own famed academy system.

"Casemiro looks lost in midfield in these first two matches," said Neville in August. "What's clear is that Manchester United's midfield needs bolstering. Ten Hag wants a No.6 who can play alongside Casemiro and at the moment the club can't get players out to fund that."

Although the club were proactive in sanctioning outgoings during the January transfer window, it was not overly necessary to create that pathway for Mainoo. He carved that out for himself by catching the eye in training and in matches while standing in for Casemiro over the winter.
They can now continue to be unleashed together.

"It was impressive and there's no point getting carried away because the reality is he's got 17 or 18 years in front of him and a lot of work to do," said Neville after Mainoo wowed on debut. "I always judge players when it's the most difficult part of the game and when Man United had their most difficult period in that first half I thought he was the only player who showed up, the only player who still looked like himself.

"The biggest compliment that I can pay him - and it hurts to say and I hope people can take that in the right spirit - he looked like a Manchester City player. I was thinking that's a player Pep Guardiola will be looking at and thinking; 'I want him in my midfield, that's what my midfield players do'."

United will take a rare (recent) win on City by holding up Mainoo as a poster boy for a brighter future. His ongoing emergence has also helped them atone for some glaring misses in the transfer market.

headline: Shola Shoretire faces uncertain Manchester United future despite contract wish
body: Man Utd hope Shola Shoretire signs a new contract but he might not have many more first team chances.
Shola Shoretire faces an uncertain future at Manchester United after dropping down the pecking order, even though the club is hoping he signs a new deal.
The academy graduate celebrated his 20th birthday on Friday and is now at an awkward crossroads where he is untested at youth level and needs to be playing regular football at senior level.

Shoretire made his first-team debut at the age of just 17 and still holds the record as the youngest player to represent United in European competition. However, he has struggled to build upon that early promise and has been overtaken in the pecking order by other academy graduates.
LATEST: £150m trio to be removed from Premier League squad after January transfer window
He has trained with the first team consistently in recent weeks and more often than he has at any other point of the season. Yet he has been overlooked.

Kobbie Mainoo was the match winner in midweek, a goal that was set up by fellow academy product Omari Forson. They, along with Alejandro Garancho, are the hottest young talents at the club, while Willy Kambwala has also been given opportunities this season.
Shoretire's struggles are a reminder of the cutthroat nature of academy football. A homegrown talent at a club like United is the next best thing until another soon emerges to take their place.

Erik ten Hag has taken on a more hands-on approach with the academy since he joined the club, having felt the U21s were 'isolated' before his arrival. He now takes an active role in deciding which youngsters train with the first team and has set the challenge for at least one youth team player to become part of the first team during every season he's at the club.

The United manager won't give youngsters an opportunity just to keep up traditions, and he has made it clear that only the very best youth prospects will be given a chance in the senior set-up. Mainoo and Garnacho fit the criteria as elite talents; Shoretire should not be ashamed that he doesn't quite fit that bracket anymore.

United are in preliminary talks with Shoretire over a new contract and still hope he agrees to new terms, as they look to protect his value in the increasingly likely scenario where he is sold in the coming years. A loan move was mooted in the January transfer window but never materialised.

While the primary task of the club's illustrious academy is to produce talent for the first team, United also accept that it can be a money-making machine. With current Financial Fair Play rules, it is hugely beneficial to a club to sell homegrown players because the profit on the sale is purely classified as income.

Isak Hansen-Aarøen was sold on deadline day, while Hannibal Mejbri moved to Sevilla on an initial loan with the option of a permanent sale, and Alvaro Fernandez left in a similar deal to join Benfica. Anthony Elanga, Zidane Iqbal, Matej Kovar, Teden Mengi, Axel Tuanzebe, Ethan Laird, Charlie Savage, Noam Emeran, and Marc Jurado were all allowed to leave last summer.
It would make sense if Shoretire was one of the next to join them in exiting the club. He has shone brightly at times, but now it looks to be in the interest of all parties if he were moved on too.
The academy not only makes world-class talent, it makes money as well.

headline: Bruno Fernandes 'rejects' Neymar chance as Manchester United told Rafael Leao transfer fee
body: The latest transfer rumours from Old Trafford involving Bruno Fernandes and AC Milan superstar Rafael Leao

Bruno Fernandes rejected a lucrative offer from Saudi Arabian outfit Al-Hilal during the January transfer window, according to reports, as the Manchester United captain pledged his future to the club while rebuffing his chance to team up with Brazil superstar Neymar in the Gulf state.

Fernandes, 29, signed for United in January 2020 and can be regarded among the best players in Europe. However, while trophies have been at a premium for the playmaker during his Old Trafford career, he has opted to stay put and spearhead their push to recapture former glories.

Reports from Portuguese publication Record flag up interest from Al-Hilal and indicate the Saudi Pro League club made every attempt to sign him last month. Al-Hilal are managed by Jorge Jesus - who worked with Fernandes at Sporting Lisbon before his switch to United.

Despite a heavy-handed attempt to bring Fernandes to the Gulf state, though, the 63-cap international is thought to have turned down that 'pharaonic proposal' to stay. The ex-Sampdoria playmaker is said to be keen on doing his utmost to ensure he wins further silverware at United after lifting the Carabao Cup last season.
Fernandes is understood to have turned down numbers that might have been 'irrefutable' to most. He would have also had the opportunity to play alongside Neymar in his twilight years.

Elsewhere, reports from Caught Offside suggest United are braced for competition from PSG and Manchester City in their mooted pursuit to snap up Raphael Leao next summer. The highly-rated AC Milan forward is claimed to have a release clause worth a staggering €175million, though any move would surely depend on whether a lower fee could be negotiated.
Leao, 24, has only scored six goals in 26 outings this season. However, his overall record for the Italian giants reads 49 goals and 42 assists from 189 matches.
He has been earmarked as a possible replacement for Kylian Mbappe on the proviso that the Frenchman signs for Real Madrid. Leao remains under contract at the San Siro until 2028.

headline: David de Gea sends message to former Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini after retirement
body: Former Man Utd goalkeeper David de Gea was among the Belgian's ex-teammates to wish him well ahead of his next sporting chapter
Former Manchester United goalkeeper David de Gea and midfielder Ander Herrera are among Marouane Fellaini's ex-teammates to send well wishes after the Belgian announced his retirement from football.

Fellaini became the first signing of the post-Sir Alex Ferguson era when he joined the club from Everton for £27.5m. He would go on to make 177 appearances for the Reds, scoring 22 goals and grabbing 12 assists.

The Belgian stayed at Old Trafford until 2019 when he made the move to the Chinese club Shandong Taishan. In an Instagram post announcing his retirement, Fellaini wrote: "What an incredible journey it has been!
"I am so grateful to have played the sport I love at the highest level. I am proud to have represented Standard in Belgium, Everton and Manchester United in the UK, and Shandong Taishan in China.

"It was an honour to have played for the Belgian national team at the Olympics of 2008, Euro 2016 and the World Cups of 2014 and 2018. I have played in front of the best fans in the world, and I want to take this moment to thank all of them for their unwavering support throughout my career. Your encouragement and passion have been a constant source of inspiration for me."

Following the news of his retirement, some of his former United teammates sent messages of good will to the midfielder. De Gea wrote: "Enjoy life brother," while Herrera added: "Congratulations amigo and all the best for your next chapter."
Jesse Lingard posted: "What a guy, enjoy big bro," and Phil Neville sent: "Congratulations Felli."

headline: Kobbie Mainoo has done something no other Manchester United player has done under Erik ten Hag
body: Man United recorded their first Premier League win of 2024 on Thursday night, beating Wolves 4-3 at Molineux, but it must mark a turning point in their season.
As a flurry of Manchester United supporters started to vacate their golden seats at Molineux, their golden boy forced them to come running back.

With 97 minutes on the clock, Kobbie Mainoo could not have selected a better moment to score his first-ever Premier League goal. Pedro Neto's 95th-minute equaliser had, it seemed, earned Wolves a point, denying United a win that would have been fully merited.

But as United's supporters prepared to criticise those all too familiar failings, such as wasted opportunities and their soft underbelly, Mainoo changed the mindset with a moment of individual brilliance. After dodging two challenges, he entered the penalty area, bent a right-footed effort towards the far corner and sent the away end barmy.

United, to their credit, had produced some of the best football they had played all season, particularly in the first half. They looked menacing every time they went forward, with full-backs Diogo Dalot and Luke Shaw providing forward runs to support Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford.

Rasmus Hojlund, who netted the second goal as a result of one of Shaw's darts to the byline, was everywhere, chasing every ball and providing a focal point at the top end of the pitch for United to aim at. His combination play with Rashford and Garnacho, as well as Bruno Fernandes, suggests Ten Hag, just as he did against Aston Villa on Boxing Day, has discovered his best trio in attack to unleash United's potential.

When Ten Hag deployed a front-three of Garnacho, Hojlund and Rashford against Villa, United scored three times, staging a brilliant second-half comeback at Old Trafford. On this occasion, United went one better and scored four for the second game running, following last weekend's dispatching of Newport County in the FA Cup at Rodney Parade.

Though only two members of the front-three got on the scoresheet at Molineux, the second-half contributions of Scott McTominay, who put United 3-1 up less than two minutes after coming off the bench, and Mainoo meant United plundered four goals in a Premier League away game for the first time since February 2022 - a 4-2 win over Leeds United at Elland Road under Ralf Rangnick.

Scoring goals by the bucketload has been a problem for United throughout Ten Hag's tenure, highlighted by this season's tally of just 28 in 22 league matches. They have only scored four goals on two occasions in the Premier League under the Dutchman's stewardship.

Nevertheless, though United's soft centre very nearly meant they exited the Black Country with just a point, they did, in the end, secure all three, which their performance so richly deserved. Their first-half showing was their best in a very long time.

After a stop-start January, which featured just one league game, February offers United the opportunity to put together a run of positive results in their bid to climb the table. They are still outsiders to finish in the top four, currently finding themselves eight points shy of Tottenham Hotspur, but the landscape of the Premier League standings can change quickly with a few good results.

Of course, United have been guilty of too many false dawns this season; they followed up a 2-1 win over Chelsea with a 3-0 defeat to Bournemouth three days later in December. This time around, perhaps because of the returns of Lisandro Martinez, Shaw and Casemiro, it feels different.

There was an identity to United's play at Molineux and it translated into scoring four goals in a Premier League game for the first time since May, and the first time in a Premier League away game in two years. Their attack, particularly in the first half, looked menacing, with Rashford hungry to prove a point after last week's off-field events, Hojlund producing a polished performance and Garnacho once again highlighting why he is a better fit on the right wing than Antony.

If United's performance at Molineux was a sign that everything is about to click into place, they need to prove it. West Ham United are up next and the Reds cannot afford to take their foot off the pedal after such a morale-boosting victory.

headline: Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund sends warning to Premier League rivals
body: Man United won 3-0 against West Ham in the Premier League with Alejandro Garnacho scoring twice and Rasmus Hojlund also on target
Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund has warned he is 'hungry' to score more goals after netting for the fourth Premier League game in a row against West Ham on Sunday afternoon.

Many felt the 4-3 victory against Wolves in midweek could be the turning point in the season and United built on that performance by securing a comfortable 3-0 win against the Hammers. Hojlund opened the scoring in the first half with an excellent finish and Alejandro Garnacho scored a brace after half-time to make sure of the result.

Hojlund spoke to MUTV after the game and made a goalscoring pledge. He said: "Reaching double figures already for such a big club is a big achievement, but I think I've said it the whole season, I'm not done. I'm hungry for more and want to keep developing, keep scoring goals, keep moving up the table and keep getting wins.

"Keep linking up with my teammates because I'm enjoying it at the moment. I think confidence is not the right word [when not scoring], you start to get a little annoyed and angry, so you lose the calmness in some situations.
"I always believed in myself, so I kept trying, and looked at my own game and what I could improve. Speaking with my teammates and the manager, asking what they see.
"We've had some talks and I've improved since I came here, so it's looking good right now. When the confidence is going, I believe I have good shots with both feet.
Hojlund was asked about playing with his attacking teammates, Marcus Rashford, Bruno Fernandes and Garnacho, and said: "A lot of excitement. Every day I come in for training and to do my job.

"I'm happy because I know I need to play with those guys, I enjoy it and you can also start seeing the connection getting good now. We're giving each other confidence and goals, involvements in the game, so I'm very happy."

headline: Erik ten Hag has a problem with his world-class Manchester United partnership
body: Man Utd could make one change to their side when they host West Ham in the Premier League today.
Erik ten Hag named his strongest Manchester United side against Wolves. They still nearly managed to throw it all away.

There were certainly positives to take from the dominant performance, and on another day, it might well have been a victory by a far bigger margin, but the harsh truth is that it wasn't. It was the same story against Newport a week ago. United could have won by a three- or four-goal margin but instead, they threw away another lead when they should have been comfortable.
Yet it would still be a surprise if they chose to make any changes today. Ten Hag has regularly cited his ambition of having a settled squad, and now he has the opportunity to do just that.
It doesn't mean they shouldn't, though. See, while it might be the strongest United side on paper, there is still an argument to suggest it could be better.

United's midfield was ripped apart at ease twice in the last week, but Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo won't be dropped, and the defence has conceded five goals in three matches when the centre-back pairing is supposed to be world-class.

Of course, keeping a clean sheet is not solely down to the centre-backs, but they are certainly a major factor. Lisandro Martinez and Raphael Varane are still widely believed to be the best two at the club, and yet the goals are still being gifted to opponents.

Martinez was off the pitch by the time Pedro Neto netted a third goal at Molineux, with Varane the unfortunate victim of United's overcommitment in the attack that left the backline exposed. There was little they could have done about the other two Wolves goals, either.

But the partnership of Martinez and Varane is still difficult to endorse due to their respective injury concerns. They have both missed a large part of the season through injuries, and the Argentine was replaced again in midweek as a precaution.

There is hope that Martinez can put his recent injury woes behind them, but the reoccurring nature of Varane's cast doubt over his long-term suitability. For all of their huge achievements—after all, they are both World Cup winners—the best ability is availability, and that is something that neither of them have nailed down this season.

Ten Hag's pursuit of consistency and momentum is being undermined by the regular changes at centre-back, and with a busy fixture schedule ahead, he needs that familiarity to stem from a settled defensive pairing.

Martinez is an integral part of the plans due to his passing ability and the different angles he opens up as a left-footer, but the plan for the summer is to sign a suitable partner for him who complements his style of play.

Varane just can't be relied upon in the long run, and Harry Maguire, who has arguably been the best-performing defender at the club this season, still doesn't seem to be the right fit for Ten Hag's desired style of play.
It is telling that now nearly everyone is available; it is Varane who has been selected over Maguire, but the real test will be keeping the Frenchman fit, which is far easier said than done.
United's defensive pairing is world-class, but only when they are actually fit.

headline: Manchester United need Alejandro Garnacho to avoid transfer embarrassment vs West Ham again
body: The early team news and main talking points as Man Utd host West Ham in the Premier League at Old Trafford today.
Manchester United will be looking to build upon their dramatic Premier League victory over Wolves when they welcome West Ham to Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon.

Erik ten Hag's side showed real character to go again after letting a two-goal lead slip in midweek, but they know they risk being punished if they don't eradicate the mistakes that so nearly cost them three points.
The return of a few more players could help United, which presents Ten Hag with a welcome conundrum as he tries to select the strongest team. Here are the main talking points:
There is more good news on the injury front, with Sofyan Amrabat and Victor Lindelof both in line to return to the squad today.

Amrabat has not played since the goalless draw with Liverpool on December 17 due to injury and his participation with Morocco at the Africa Cup of Nations. Lindelof has been sidelined since December 6 after undergoing groin surgery.
Neither of the players will go into the starting lineup, but they will at least give Ten Hag some more experienced options to call upon from the bench.
Crisis? What crisis? Rasmus Hojlund took a while to adapt to the Premier League, but now it looks like he has finally settled and will only get better.

Like all great goalscorers, the Danish forward was in the right place at the right time to score goals against Newport and Wolves, and he looks full of confidence for the first time in a United shirt.

Hojlund now has three goals and two assists across his last four appearances and is also doing a lot of the dirty work as well. Just as impressive as his goal against Wolves was a brilliant piece of hold-up play in the first half when he used a combination of silk and steel to take the ball past opposition players before unleashing a perfect pass for Marcus Rashford.
We know he can score goals in the Premier League. The next challenge is to do it on a consistent basis.
It is hard to recall any poor performances from Kobbie Mainoo in a United shirt so far. But his worst was certainly the defeat to West Ham two days before Christmas.
The 18-year-old largely looked calm and composed in possession but made a costly error when he failed to control a simple pass to set up Mohammed Kudus for the second goal of the match.
Mainoo has already come a long way since that tough afternoon at the London Stadium, and today he will be looking to prove that those mistakes really are a rarity in his rise to the top.

Speaking of that trip to the London Stadium back in December, it is hard to ignore Kudus again. It felt inevitable he would score in that meeting on a day when former teammate Antony had another performance to forget.
Of all the Ajax players Ten Hag could have signed, Kudus was arguably the one best suited to their attacking line. He cost less than half the price as well.

The Ghanaian is back from the Africa Cup of Nations and won a vital penalty for West Ham on Thursday night, shortly before Antony nearly cost his team with his careless loss of possession that led to a late Wolves equaliser.
United will hope to subdue Kudus this time around, but rather than a battle against Antony, he will have to try and outshine Alejandro Garnacho instead. It'll be a tough ask.
Garnacho has made the right-wing role his own in recent weeks and was excellent from out wide in midweek as well. Many fans would swap Kudus for Antony, but they wouldn't swap him for Garnacho.

United are unbeaten in their last 15 Premier League home games against West Ham (W12 D3), winning each of the last three 1-0. The last team to win four consecutive home games against an opponent by the same scoreline was Sunderland against Man City, who beat them 1-0 four times in a row at the Stadium of Light between 2010 and 2013.
West Ham haven't beaten United in the league at Old Trafford since their famous final-day victory in 2007. It was also the last time they completed a league double against them.

The history books certainly back United to win again today, but recent records provide plenty of doubt. West Ham have earned 17 points from their 11 away league games so far this season (W5 D2 L4), already five more than they earned on the road in the whole of last season.

Old Trafford isn't a fortress either. United have conceded seven goals in their last three Premier League home games, going down 3-0 against Bournemouth, beating Aston Villa 3-2, and drawing 2-2 with Spurs. They’ve not conceded multiple goals in four consecutive home league games since November–January 1971–72.

headline: Erik ten Hag names two Rasmus Hojlund attributes that convinced Manchester United to sign him
body: Rasmus Hojlund is starting to find his feet at Man Utd and Erik ten Hag has praised his attitude and character to keep going during a difficult season.
Erik ten Hag has praised Rasmus Hojlund's "resilience and calmness" after lauding his £72millon striker for starting to live up to the expectations he has set himself at Manchester United.

The 20-year-old endured a difficult start to his Old Trafford career in a team that was losing its way, but although the goals didn't flow for Hojlund, his attitude never changed and he never went missing.

Ten Hag revealed the striker was getting "angry and mad" as he went 14 Premier League games without a goal since his summer switch from Atalanta, but after breaking his duck against Aston Villa he has now scored in three successive top-flight games, taking his tally in all competitions to nine this season.

Hojlund has played more often than United expected this season, playing 66% of available minutes and only Andre Onana, Bruno Fernandes and Diogo Dalot have played more minutes than Hojlund's 1,911 in all competitions.

There is a feeling he has been thrown in at the deep end at United, with Anthony Martial suffering from injury and inconsistency and Hojlund taking on the mantle of starting striker when he remained relatively inexperienced, having had a rapid rise in the 18 months since FC Copenhagen sold him to Sturm Graz.
But Ten Hag is beginning to see the traits that convinced him Hojlund was the right man this summer and they are mental attributes as much as physical ones.
"I can tell you it’s not easy for a striker when you have high expectations from yourself, also the outside world has high expectations, to fulfil that when it’s not working," explained Ten Hag.
"That is the character every striker needs, he gets angry, he gets mad when he’s not scoring, but that’s why we selected him, he has the resilience and the calmness to perform under that stress.

"He doesn’t have any moment that he wants to give up, he keeps going every time to put himself in the right position. I’m happy he now starts to score, but it counts for many young players there is a lot of space for improvement, but he’s still now on very good levels."

Hojlund has scored in Premier League games against Aston Villa, Tottenham and Wolves, as well as finding the net in the FA Cup fourth-round win at Newport County. He also teed up Marcus Rashford for his redemptive opener at Molineux on Thursday and Ten Hag believes there is a partnership forming between his attacking stars.
"He is a great character, he always keeps going, always wants to improve," he said. "You see now the team is better and more stable, now we serve the front line better and he starts scoring.
"You see there is something growing with Rashy, with Garnacho, with Bruno, also other players from the second and the third line. He is coming more in a position to score."

headline: Leroy Sane said I was the toughest opponent he faced but I never made it at Manchester United
body: "I didn’t play much and I wanted to. It was the best decision in the end to go somewhere else where I would get more minutes."
"When you are 22, 23, 24 years old you need to be playing.
"I didn’t play much and I wanted to.
"It was the best decision in the end to go somewhere else where I would get more minutes."
Timothy Fosu-Mensah had good intentions when he left Manchester United three years ago, but now he must wonder whether he would have been better off staying instead.
The Dutch defender is now 26 years old and is nowhere near as close to starting games on a regular basis as he would have hoped when he turned down a new contract and left to join Bayer Leverkusen.

It began well with six starts in a row following his January move in 2021. But then came the first of a string of serious injuries that have limited him to just 30 appearances in three years. He has spent 935 days injured in his professional career and has been unavailable for 146 games as a result.
FEATURE: I rejected Liverpool to sign for United and then quit City medical for Arsenal

It is staggering to realise Fosu-Mensah has still played for the United first team as many times as he has for Leverkusen and only mustered 1,014 minutes of action in the last three years. Last season, 15 appearances were spread out over just 196 minutes. He hasn't made one competitive appearance so far this campaign.

As he nears a return to fitness, he will be desperate to step out on the pitch again in the coming weeks, but Leverkusen are a very different team from when he arrived. Xabi Alonso is the manager, Jeremie Frimpong is a superstar in his preferred position and Leverkusen lead Bayern Munich in the Bundesliga title race.
It's a far cry from the hype that followed him at United when he was one of the brightest young talents in the Premier League and feared by former Man City ace Leroy Sane.

"It was before when I was playing against Kyle Walker. And Crystal Palace's right-back Timothy Fosu-Mensah, I have played against him twice this season, and even last season, he had me really well under control and I told him how happy I was to play against him," he said of his toughest opponents.
That was during one of two Premier League loan spells Fosu-Mensah would go on during his time at United, with the Dutch defender rated highly enough to get opportunities at both Palace and Fulham.

The versatile defender made his debut for United under Louis van Gaal, winning the FA Cup in his debut season as a senior player when he was just 18. He might have feared for his place when Jose Mourinho arrived the following summer but he still featured 11 times under the Portuguese coach, lifting the League Cup and the Europa League in his first term.
Those experiences made him a more developed player, even if the treatment was harsh at times.

“I spent the full [2016/17] season with the first team and as a result of that, I completed a full pre-season with them for the first time," he said. “I was still a teenager when Jose Mourinho arrived and he helped me mature into becoming a man in footballing terms.

“Jose was tough on young players with his demands but in a good way because he wanted you to be ready to represent a club the size of Manchester United. He helped make me stronger mentally and physically.
“I remember playing against Northampton Town in the early rounds of the League Cup – which we went on to win at the end of the season – and I did not have my best game.

“He subbed me after 60 minutes and we had a Europa League game coming up a week or so after the League Cup game, which I did not think I had a chance of playing in after he subbed me off. However, he started me in the Europa League game and I played the full game which gave me confidence to continue to grow at the club.
"We went on to win the Europa League against Ajax at the end of the season and that was a great achievement for the club.
“Overall, I have to say that I really enjoyed working under Jose Mourinho. He was really good with me as a young player. He is open-minded and he is a very good manager, as his career has shown.”
Mourinho's treatment of young players is well documented but what was so tough for Fosu-Mensah was that not even key ally Ole Gunnar Solskjaer could find a regular place for him in the squad.

Those two loan exits had been sanctioned by Mourinho and the second was cut short when he suffered a knee ligament injury, which saw him return to United in the closing stages of the 2018–19 season. By the time he returned, there was a new manager in the Old Trafford hot seat.

Fosu-Mensah watched from the sidelines as the United hero went about rebuilding the squad and then, against all the odds, he got opportunities he never expected due to the curtailed pandemic campaign. In June of 2020, Fosu-Mensah made his first United senior matchday squad since May 2017 as he sat on the bench in an FA Cup tie against Norwich.

A month later, with Luke Shaw and Brandon Williams both out injured, Solskjaer called on him to start at left-back ahead of Diogo Dalot against former side Palace at Selhurst Park. He would make another four appearances in the final matches of the season, including in semi-final defeats of both the FA Cup and Europa League.
The Dutch defender was now fully fit, confident, and raring to go into the new campaign. He was desperate to get his chance and he got one right away. Things didn't go according to plan.

He started right back in the opening-day defeat to Crystal Palace but after a poor performance, he was dropped again. Fosu-Mensah only featured from the bench twice more in Champions League defeats away to Istanbul Basaksehir and RB Leipzig.

He would never play for the club again. Fosu-Mensah rejected a new contract as he felt 'undervalued' by the terms offered. Those close to the player insisted he was sad to be leaving but 'excited to get a fresh start and show people what he was really capable of.'

"It was my decision," he later reiterated. "The manager was good to me but at the end, I was not playing a lot. When you are 22, 23, or 24 years old you need to be playing. I didn’t play much and I wanted to. It was the best decision in the end to go somewhere else where I would get more minutes.

“The club and the manager were good to me. I recovered from a big injury; they helped me and gave me minutes. I played in the FA Cup semi-final and the Europa League semi-final. But it’s important to play regularly and to get my opportunity in the national team too.

“Ole has been very good to me. I spoke with him because he had a big injury as a player so he knew exactly how I felt. When I played against Crystal Palace after 16 months, he was very happy for me. These were very good moments. He knew I had the quality. I have no bad things to say about him because he has been very good to me."

It's a real shame that three years later he is back where he was to begin with: looking to prove himself after another serious injury. Fosu-Mensah should be praised for taking the risk to leave the club when he had doubts about his future and if there is anyone who deserves a slice of luck, it is him.
Leverkusen and United fans will be happy to see him back. Leroy Sane might not be so happy to face him again.

headline: Getafe boss defends Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood amid Jude Bellingham 'slur' allegation
body: A La Liga investigation is underway to determine what Jude Bellingham might have said against Getafe.

Getafe manager Jose Bordalas has jumped to the defence of Mason Greenwood and called for 'respect' to be shown towards the Manchester United loanee after Jude Bellingham was reported to La Liga for allegedly aiming him a ‘slur’ at him.
The Spanish top flight has announced they have asked a lip reader to determine whether or not Real Madrid midfielder Bellingham aimed the alleged slur toward Greenwood in their midweek clash.
It all stems from an incident during Real Madrid's 2-0 win on Thursday night, when the television cameras caught Bellingham mouthing something after the ball went out of play.
LATEST: £150m trio to be removed from Premier League squad after January transfer window

A La Liga statement released following the incident read: "Getafe yesterday transferred the complaint to the La Liga match director. La Liga, as it always does on these occasions, has requested an expert report on lip reading to investigate the matter and act on the basis of what can be proven beyond doubt (by the lip reader)."
Bordalas said: ‘I know the same thing that you know. It’s not up to me, it’s the club, La Liga and the Federation that have to make an assessment about it.
"The only thing that I can say is that I ask for respect from Mason Greenwood because he is a great guy.
"He is a man who respects everyone and has exemplary behaviour.’"
If charged and found guilty by the Spanish football authorities, Bellingham could be handed a potential suspension as a result.
Greenwood has not played for United since January 2022, after allegations were made against him on social media that month.

United conducted an internal investigation after the Crown Prosecution Service announced in February last year that it had dropped charges of attempted rape, assault and coercive control. United informed Greenwood that he would have to resume his career elsewhere in August.

headline: I was David Moyes' first signing at Manchester United and a tattoo damaged my career
body: Guillermo Varela was David Moyes' first signing as Man United manager and there were high hopes for the defender.

The history books show Guillermo Varela was the first signing of the post-Sir Alex Ferguson era. Varela officially became David Moyes' first signing when joining United from Penarol in June 2013, but many considered the transfer as Ferguson's parting gift.

That's because Varela had undergone a successful trial in the final months of Ferguson's reign and a deal had been negotiated before Moyes took up his position. The legendary Scot believed Varela had the potential to become an outstanding right-back, however, he was unable to nail down a regular starting position under three different United managers.
“I was younger so it was difficult to come to Manchester United and try to play at 20 years old - I'm not Rashford," Varela said in an interview with The Sun in 2019.
Varela was just 20 years old when he moved to Manchester and he spent the 2013/14 season playing in the academy before the decision was made to send him on loan.
The defender joined Real Madrid's reserve side, who were managed by Zinedine Zidane. “I was with the Castilla team under Zidane for one year," Varela said.

"I would train two or three times a week with the first team. It was magnificent. With Cristiano, Karim Benzema, Gareth Bale as well. I spoke with Cristiano about Manchester United. Chicharito (Hernández) moved at the same time with me. We lived separately but he was very helpful.”
Varela made 33 appearances for Real Madrid Castilla and he was named in the first team's squad for the Champions League. The spell was a success and a return to United followed.
Louis van Gaal was in charge by then and he provided Varela with a string of appearances, with the right-back making his United senior bow against West Ham in December 2015.
"I have been pleased with the progress of the younger players when they've been called to train with the first-team squad so I am not afraid of using them if required," Van Gaal said.

Just three days later, Varela made his first start for United when playing in a 3-2 defeat to Wolfsburg, a result which sealed the Reds' exit from the Champions League. However, Matteo Darmian was Van Gaal's first-choice right-back and he continued to be selected for the majority of games, which meant Varela had to be patient for starts.

That patience was rewarded in February 2016 when Darmian sustained an injury, which meant Varela started in the second leg of the Europa League Round of 32 against FC Midtjylland. Varela assisted Marcus Rashford in a comfortable 5-1 win and he was one of the best performers that night, which saw him retain his place for the Round of 16 clash against Liverpool.
Liverpool won the first leg 2-0 at Anfield and Varela started again in the reverse fixture, but what happened next essentially ended his time at the club.
Anthony Martial opened the scoring with a penalty in the 32nd minute, but Liverpool equalised just before half-time when Phillipe Coutinho burst down the left and went around Varela.
Coutinho made beating Varela look simple before he dinked the ball over David de Gea and that mistake was enough for Van Gaal to hook him during the interval.
"It is football," Varela later said about his performance and substitution against Liverpool. “Van Gaal gave me the chance to play so I have to say thank you. He is a crazy coach.

"He was always angry with the players but it was good. I enjoyed it. I played 11 matches. I enjoyed every single one. I played one game in the Champions League, I played in the Europa League. Playing for Manchester United is amazing. Of course, it was a dream.

“Growing up, it was always about Manchester United, ahead of Real Madrid and Barcelona, because of Diego Forlan playing there. So for a player from Uruguay, it was a dream to play for Manchester United. He was my hero.
“But I had to play more. At Manchester United, playing only one or two games a month was not good. I had to play every game and at Manchester United that was difficult.”
Varela featured in a handful of first-team and academy matches during the remainder of that season, so it wasn't a surprise to see him omitted from the 2016 FA Cup final squad.

Van Gaal was sacked after victory against Crystal Palace in that final and Jose Mourinho was named as his successor. The Portuguese took his first pre-season match against Wigan and Varela came on from the bench, but there was no room for him on the subsequent tour of China.

United embarked on their pre-season tour and Varela was sent on loan again, this time to Eintracht Frankfurt. He was now 23 and aware he needed a run of consistent matches. But disaster struck in just Varela's third appearance for Frankfurt when he suffered torn ankle ligaments, which required surgery and a screw inserted into his leg.

Varela returned to action after five months on the sidelines, but he was still struggling with pain caused by the injury, so he underwent further surgery. Although the injury meant he was unavailable for the DFB-Pokal Cup final against Borussia Dortmund, it was suggested his absence was actually due to an infected tattoo.
Varela had received fresh ink during his spell on the sidelines and it allegedly caused inflammation of his arm. Frankfurt reacted by suspending him and ordering his return to Manchester.
"My name is polluted. I wonder what Real Madrid should do with Sergio Ramos, who is tattooing every week," Varela reacted at the time, trying to protest his innocence.
"I cannot explain why I'm being so severely punished, and I'm not the only Eintracht professional to get a tattoo before the final, but only I was nailed to the cross for going against the manager.

"Before the 2016 FA Cup final [against Crystal Palace], we went out with several players and got a tattoo, and then we won. Now I wanted to repeat that because it brought us so much luck with Manchester."

Frankfurt's sporting director responded: "The club cannot tolerate that a player would defy instructions. He hurt the team. There was redness around where he had the tattoo, and blisters formed meaning he was unable to train.
"We'd been thinking about a loan extension. But that won't happen. He'll be suspended with immediate effect."

A few years later, Varela attempted to clarify the tattoo situation. “I got a tattoo at the top of my back on my neck," he said. "It was during my injury, while I was not playing, about three months before the final in May.
“[Manager] Niko Kovac said to me, 'I don't want you to get any more tattoos.' I said, 'Why? I'm injured'. He said, 'Yes, I know but you have to respect the players and the staff.'
“I said, 'Okay, I understand but I am injured.' Then when I started to play again I got this one done on my arm [a woman's face].

"He said to me, 'No, no, no. You stop here because we have the final in one week and I told you before you have to finish with your tattoos so now you are out.' I didn't get infected, that's not true. It was just because I got it.”

Varela returned to Manchester after a disappointing spell with Frankfurt but had no regrets. "I talked to Jose Mourinho and we talked about my future and what would be best for me," he told the Manchester Evening News.
"He was very sincere towards me. He told me my playing time would be little so my decision was that I preferred to go. A player needs to play and that's what I sought in Frankfurt."

Varela was sold by Mourinho in the summer of 2017 and he re-signed for Penarol. "I really learnt a lot from the way he [Mourinho] trained - the ball was always in the centre of the exercises," he said.
"The relationship was very good and I was pleasantly surprised. Maybe I expected his character when he is confronted with the press, but that was definitely not the case.
"He's always asking how everyone feels, making no difference between Rooney or a player who has just come up. He was always joking and ensuring he had a good connection between everyone and himself."
His time at United came to an underwhelming end and, at the time, a source close to the player told the MEN that he returned to his former club for 'personal tranquillity'.
"The player decided [to join Penarol] after how badly he was treated in Frankfurt. His experience in Europe was not good," they said.
Varela left having made 11 first-team appearances for United and he also scored an injury-time winner as the club's Under-21s won the academy Premier League title in 2016.
Many fans were disappointed to see Varela leave the club and he got his career back on track with Penarol before eventually returning to Europe in January 2019.

Varela signed for FC Copenhagen and it was there he admitted he would love a return to Old Trafford in the future. “It would be a dream to go back to Old Trafford. It would be a beautiful moment," he said.

"I wait for this. Maybe we will get drawn to play Manchester United - we don't know. But if we do, it would be a dream. Maybe we will meet again soon. Maybe in the Europa League, maybe in the Premier League.
“I'm still only 26. I of course want to go back to the Premier League at some point. In the future, maybe I can come back and play for Manchester United - I hope.
“I would say thank you to the fans. I want to say thank you for a beautiful four years, thank you for your support.”

Varela was denied his wish of a return to Old Trafford by the pandemic because when United drew Copenhagen in the quarter-finals of the Europa League in 2020, it was a one-off match and played at a neutral venue in Germany. Nonetheless, he started the game and was brought off in extra time.
Varela made over 50 appearances for Copenhagen and played a similar number of games when signing for Dynamo Moscow, but he desired a return to South America.
Since the summer of 2022, Varela has played for Brazilian club Flamengo and represented Uruguay at the Qatar World Cup.
He has finally found his 'personal tranquillity' at 30 years old.

headline: Why Manchester United loanee Jadon Sancho missed Borussia Dortmund game
body: Manchester United's winger Jadon Sancho missed Borussia Dortmund's draw with Heidenheim in the Bundesliga on Friday night
Manchester United loanee Jadon Sancho missed Borussia Dortmund's draw with Heidenheim on Friday night due to an injury.

Sancho joined the Bundesliga giants on loan in January after a public fallout with United manager Erik ten Hag. Following the defeat to Arsenal in September, the Red Devils boss explained the winger's performances in training were behind the decision not to select him.

The 23-year-old took issue with this, branding himself a 'scapegoat' and suggesting his training performances were not below par. Despite the social media statement being deleted, Sancho refused to apologise for his comments and was promptly banished from the first team.

In January, United wasted little time getting Sancho off the books and agreed to a loan switch to his old club Dortmund. Following his arrival, the forward has made three appearances and bagged two assists in the process.
However, he did not feature in the clash yesterday due to injury. Discussing the issue, Sancho's boss Edin Terzic explained it was a muscular problem.

"Jadon currently has muscular problems in the adductor area, which is not surprising after his long break," he said. "We will wait and see how things develop over the next two days and decide at short notice whether he will travel with us to Heidenheim."
As it transpires, Sancho was not fit enough to make the journey and missed the clash. It is not clear as of yet when he will return to the starting line-up.
The winger will have two years remaining on his United contract at the end of the season. However, the forward is expected to leave the club permanently at the culmination of his loan spell.

headline: Manchester United's quiet January transfer window lays down the gauntlet for Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United did not make any new signings during the January transfer window despite a disappointing season so far, so the pressure is on Sir Jim Ratcliffe to deliver this summer
Heading into the January transfer window, Manchester United supporters were keen to see new faces.

United have underperformed so far this season as injuries, a loss of form and disciplinary matters plagued the squad, leading to a Champions League exit and an uphill battle to secure a top-four finish. Erik ten Hag admitted to wanting a new striker in the January transfer window following the victory over Wolverhampton Wanderers in the Premier League. Alas, United stuck to their guns this winter.

Before the window opened, club officials stressed they were not interested in conducting major business in January - and that stance preceded no new signings. However, this did not stop the club from completing a host of departures: several academy players and fringe stars departed on loan, notably Donny van de Beek, Hannibal Mejbri and Facundo Pellistri.

The biggest exit from a United perspective came as Jadon Sancho left on loan to join Borussia Dortmund. Crucially though, the Bundesliga giants have confirmed they will find it difficult to make this switch permanent in the summer. This news, coupled with the lack of signings means this window could be considered below par among the fanbase. Sir Jim Ratcliffe and INEOS have a huge summer ahead of them, with multiple areas of the squad needing quality.

By the time the next window opens, Ratcliffe should have had his investment in United ratified by the Premier League and his staff will be tasked with rebuilding the club. Plenty of new signings will be expected but departures shall also be necessary to shake off the burden of Premier League Profit and Sustainability Regulations (PSR).
The big question is: what do you think of United's January business? Let us know in our poll above, and get involved in the debate in the comments section.

headline: Former Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini retires from football
body: Marouane Fellaini arrived at Old Trafford from Everton in August 2013 and went on to score 22 goals in 177 appearances.

Former Manchester United midfielder Marouane Fellaini has announced his retirement from professional football at the age of 36. Fellaini became David Moyes' first United signing in a £27.5 million move from Everton on deadline day in 2013. He went on to win the FA Cup, the League Cup and the Europa League during his five-and-a-half years at Old Trafford, scoring 22 goals in 177 appearances.
The former Everton midfielder was criticised for much of his United career but has been given more credit in later years than he did at the time.

Fellaini was mocked for what he represented as much as anything, with United often resorting to him when they ran out of ideas in the closing stages of matches and grew desperate. He was also synonymous with the club's transfer failure, having ended up being United's sole summer signing in a season in which the club finished seventh and Moyes was sacked after just 10 months in charge.
OPINION: Mainoo has done something no other player has done under Ten Hag
His best spell of football came when he won three trophies under Jose Mourinho and proved to be an effective option from the bench.

Fellaini only played 31 minutes under United caretaker coach Ole Gunnar Solskjaer before he was sold to Chinese Super League side Shandong Luneng Taishan in a deal worth around £10million back in 2019.

Speaking after his exit, the Belgian insisted he had no regrets about leaving the club after Mourinho had been sacked: "He (Solskjaer) didn’t have a conversation with me if I will play or not. I signed a new contract for two years, one of the best managers in the world wanted me to stay.
"But after that, when a new manager comes and I’m not in his plans, of course it was time for me to leave and I don’t regret it at all."
He was also part of the Belgium side that finished third at the 2018 World Cup, during an international career that saw him score 18 goals in 87 appearances.

headline: Kylian Mbappe could hand Manchester United transfer blow and other rumours
body: The latest Manchester United news and rumours as we take a look at two of the latest reports swirling around Old Trafford.

Reported Manchester United target Rafael Leao has been identified by Paris Saint Germain as a potential replacement for Kylian Mbappe, according to ESPN. Mbappe is out of contract with the French giants in the summer and a decision is yet to be made over his future.

He has been heavily linked with a move to Real Madrid. If that’s the case, Leao has been identified as a ‘replacement’ by PSG. United were linked with an interest in the AC Milan forward back in November.
Leao only signed a new five-year deal in June meaning that Milan are expected to ask for a big fee. Manchester City have also been linked with an interest in the 24-year-old.

It is claimed that the forward has a release clause of €175 million in his contract, although clubs could try to negotiate a lower fee. His numbers have not been so good this season, having scored six goals in 26 outings.
In other news, Erik ten Hag’s future at United could depend on how much money he is given to spend in the summer transfer window, reports have suggested.

There has been speculation over his future at Old Trafford following the takeover by INEOS. When the summer comes around he will have one year remaining on his current deal after taking over in the summer of 2022, United do have the option of triggering a 12-month extension last year.

The Mirror now suggest that the United boss has been left ‘frustrated’ by being unable to make a loan signing in the January transfer window, despite losing Anthony Martial to injury. The report adds that he feels there has been a ‘lack of consistent backing’ in the transfer market for him to put his own stamp on the squad.

It is said that Ten Hag ‘wants answers’ on whether he will be given money to spend on new signings when the summer transfer window opens United have spent around £400 million on new arrivals since Ten Hag has been in charge.

headline: Four Manchester United players leave on loan deals
body: Man United have developed innovative loan moves for their players and four players have made switches on January transfer deadline day.
Manchester United youngsters Sam Mather, Sam Murray, Sonny Aljofree and Tom Wooster have signed innovative loan deals.
United created a flexi-loan system last season, which allows youngsters to gain senior experience whilst remaining involved in the day-to-day environment at Carrington.

⁠Sam Mather (Rochdale), Sam Murray (Rochdale), Sonny Aljofree (Altrincham) and Tom Wooster (Macclesfield) are the latest to sign such deals. They have all joined Greater Manchester clubs and United believe that is further evidence of the academy's support of local football.
The initiative will enable all four players to play senior football whilst still having the opportunity to play for and train with the academy.
It's understood the youngsters will benefit from a bespoke and flexible programme, with coaches able to make decisions on their schedule week-by-week.
Mather, 19, recently returned from a long-term injury and he scored four goals for the Under-21s against Norwich last weekend. He will spend time with Rochdale.
Murray, 19, will also gain experience with Rochdale. Mather and Murray were both part of the Under-18 side that won the FA Youth Cup in the 2021/22 season.
Maxi Oyedele, Joe Hugill and Aljofree were the first players to leave United as part of the innovative scheme last year. Aljofree spent time with Altrincham and he's re-signed for the club.
Goalkeeper Wooster, 18, joins Macclesfield after having a traditional loan stint with Ramsbottom United last term.

headline: Manchester United Under-18s continue flawless league record with victory against Liverpool
body: Man United's Under-18s have been in excellent form this season and they still have a flawless record in the league.
Manchester United Under-18s extended their flawless league record with a 4-3 win against Liverpool on Tuesday night.
The youngsters have taken their division by storm and their victory over Liverpool means they have won all 14 of their games.
Ethan Wheatley, Jayce Fitzgerald, Ethan Williams and James Scanlon all got on the scoresheet and United went behind twice before fighting back to win the match.
The result also extended the U18s' lead at the top of the table by 17 points. United last won the U18 league in 2017/18 and they could wrap up the title in the coming weeks.
Manchester City's U18s won the title last season and they currently sit second in the table. They have two games in hand over United.
United were expected to go deep in the FA Youth Cup this term and they were stunned when being knocked out of the competition by Swindon Town earlier this month.

Adam Lawrence took charge of the U18s in the summer and he spoke to the MEN before Christmas. "Young players are competitive individuals - they want to win games, they want to perform at a good level," he said when asked about the flawless league run.

"I think it's testament to the group that since pre-season, you've seen the development and the way that the team has evolved up until now, the individual development within that and then the style and some of the football the lads have played.
"There's a lot to go after in terms of the bigger picture, but a lot of like really good moments in games as well so far."

headline: Manchester United starlet scores four goals in Old Trafford win including 15-minute hat-trick
body: Man Utd U21s thumped Norwich at Old Trafford and one youngster caught the eye with a remarkable hat-trick.
In a season largely of disappointment for Manchester United, their youth teams continue to be a beacon of light to be proud of.

On Saturday lunchtime, the U18s made nine changes to their side and still thrashed Leeds to maintain their flawless start to the new campaign with 13 wins from 13. A couple of hours later, the U21s continued where they left off with an emphatic victory over Norwich at Old Trafford.

United are well aware that positive results are simply a by-product of all the hard work that goes on at the youth level, and the real success of their illustrious academy is that 249 players have emerged from it to make their competitive debuts for the club.
MOST READ: Sevilla issue Hannibal statement after he is made unavailable for selection

A week after United held their annual academy event at Old Trafford, it was the turn of the U21s to showcase why they should be the next in line to get a first-team opportunity. Head of the Academy, Nick Cox, said he was genuinely intrigued to know who the next would be. It might not be Sam Mather, but he could well be one of the following crop to do so.

The 19-year-old was one of the key players when United won the FA Youth Cup two years ago, scoring two goals on their road to the final. Two of his teammates from that side, Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho, are now shining for the first team. He has every right to dream of that himself.

Mather's progress has been halted by injury since that youth team triumph and now he looks to be making up for lost time. It only took him fifteen minutes to net a stunning first-half hat-trick on Saturday afternoon.
Those memorable nights in the Youth Cup had Mather well used to playing at Old Trafford and he looked right at home when he calmly fired in at the back post to give his side an early lead.

He almost had a second when his low shot was saved by Dan Barden, but the Norwich 'keeper could do nothing about his next effort when United won a free kick about 25 yards out from goal and Mather expertly fired it into the top right corner of the goal.

It means a lot to the Salford-born winger to get these opportunities and even more that he has been able to take them. Five minutes after his stunning free kick, he fired another low effort just wide of goal from outside the box.

What will please his coaches most, though, is that he also knows how to do the simple stuff. If you put yourself in the right areas, you will score a lot of goals. He did just that when he tapped in a third from a matter of yards out after James Scanlon's initial effort had been saved.

He not only had three goals in 15 minutes, but he could quite easily have had five. But if you don't take those chances, you will be punished. Norwich didn't have many but got one back on the stroke of half time when Ken Aboh fired into the bottom corner after a brilliant solo run.

Norwich were much improved after the restart but when a player is in red-hot form, there is little you can do. United worked the ball well on the edge of the box and when it reached Mather at the back post, he cut inside and curled a beautiful effort into the far corner of the net.

The only annoyance is that United's dominance wasn't so obvious by the end. A calamitous defensive mix-up allowed Adian Manning the simplest of tap-ins into an open net and Norwich should have had another when Aboh fired over from a tight angle inside the box.
In a month when United sources claim any move for a new forward would have to be "exceptionally economical," there would be no greater example than promoting someone from the youth ranks instead.
United are in desperate need of another goal-scoring forward. Mather is one of them.

headline: Manchester United youngster Dan Gore explains Port Vale loan decision
body: The 19-year-old midfielder will spend the rest of the season at the League One club, and has explained why Port Vale was the place that attracted him the most for his loan spell
Manchester United midfielder Dan Gore has spoken about his loan move to Port Vale and why he chose the League One side as his home for the rest of the season.

A number of clubs, including Preston and Bolton Wanderers, had expressed an interest during this month's transfer window in taking the 19-year-old on board, but - with guidance from his father - it was the Potteries side that won the day and he could make his debut this weekend against Portsmouth.
The MEN reported yesterday how United had agreed on Port Vale as Gore's destination because of the way they play and their support system for young players.
He said: "Well, I think from the first time I've come here to see the place and meet everyone, I just knew straight away. Because I got a feeling it's just like a family. Everyone was very welcoming.
"I've obviously seen Port Vale play and they play very good football.

"My dad was shocked. He was like: 'Son, you've got to go there'. He just knew they'd take care of me and obviously, at this stage of my career, I need that because I'm still developing. He knew, straight away, he got the best feeling from here."

Gore is friends with Vale's Manchester-born midfielder Tommy McDermott, who also urged him to agree to the switch, and he'll also see familiar faces there in the guise of ex-Reds Tom Sang and James Wilson.
"Tommy said definitely go, it'll be the best experience for you," added Gore. "You'll develop really well.
"I can guarantee hard work and determination to do everything for the badge; to do our best to try to get the three points in every game. The most important thing is winning.
"I trained Monday and Tuesday and they went really good. I trained hard and am looking forward to keeping going."

headline: Manchester United 'considering options' after controversial cup exit following Aston Villa error
body: Manchester United will not progress to the last eight of the Continental League Cup as a result of the FA punishing Aston Villa Women, but not expelling them from the competition altogether

Manchester United say they are "very disappointed" and are 'considering their options' following an FA ruling which has seen them dumped out of the Continental League Cup as a result of Aston Villa's administrative error.

The Reds' 2-1 defeat to Manchester City last week saw them finish second in Group B, with their otherwise exemplary record in this season's competition meaning they were set to advance to the last eight as one of two best-placed runners-up. However, Aston Villa's decision to field January signing Noelle Maritz in their 7-0 win over Sunderland has had a knock-on effect on Marc Skinner's side, who will now not progress to the knockout stages.

Maritz, who moved to Bescot Stadium from Women's Super League (WSL) rivals Arsenal earlier this month, was introduced in the second half against Sunderland, despite already being cup-tied. She had featured three times for the Gunners in the competition earlier in the season, starring against Bristol City, Southampton and Tottenham Hotspur.
READ | Major Morgan Rogers to Aston Villa transfer update as third bid tabled
READ |  Tielemans starts, Bailey returns - Aston Villa starting XI vs Newcastle picked

As a result, her introduction against Sunderland was in breach of Conti Cup rule 8.14 - which deals with the fielding of an ineligible player - and the points for the contest have instead been awarded to the Black Cats. An FA statement released on Monday said: "An independent tribunal have deducted three points from Aston Villa for fielding an ineligible player during their FA Women’s Continental Tyres League Cup group stage fixture against Sunderland on Wednesday 24 January 2024.

"The FA alleged that the player was ineligible for this game, as she had previously featured in the competition for her former club, which constitutes a breach of Cup Rule 8.19. Aston Villa admitted this charge and acknowledged the breach had occurred. The independent tribunal ordered that the points deducted from Aston Villa be awarded to their opponents Sunderland, while the 7-0 scoreline is to be expunged from the record.
"As a result, Sunderland will finish as Group A winners, with Aston Villa progressing to the quarter-finals as one of the two best-placed runners-up alongside Tottenham Hotspur."

Responding to the news, a Manchester United spokesperson said: "We are very disappointed with this outcome and do not understand its rationale. We feel that it undermines the integrity of the competition and of the women's game. We are considering our options in response."
United have won three of their four games in the Conti Cup this term, beating Everton 7-0, Liverpool 1-0 and Leicester City 3-1.
